A little annoying.Bearing the fact we were staying so close to Times Square in mind, I took earplugs and hoped for the best.The first night we were so jet lagged we fell asleep about 7pm (and woke up at 4am) No problems at all. The only thing that woke me was the next room coming in about 9pm after a meal and letting the door slam shut. The doors are quite noisey.The rest of the holiday the only noise we heard from the hotel was the occasional door slam (from the highly inconsiderate neighbours next door).Outside, there was a lorry-loading area which was the main problem. It started about 4am and didn't stop for an hour. Basically, they load metal pipes and things onto the lorries which then drive off. Reversing beeps, the noise of the carriers being loaded and the drivers and workers swearing and laughing at each other kept me awake, however with ear-plugs this wasn't a problem, and I slept like a baby! We also found the window wasn't quite shut properly (despite the fact they shouldn't have been opened) so once we closed it properly that muted the sounds a little.I would definately reccommend earplugs if you're a light sleeper. My bloke is a heavy sleeper and didn't hear a thing!• Pros and ConsPRO'sFantastic locationGreat staffAmazing roomBreakfast choice was brilliantCheap for the location!Any problems we had (Like the next room smoking which made ours smell disgusting) were quickly attended to.CON'sNoise (only if you're a very light sleeper)
My first visit in New York, we didn't know where to stay, then, by walk, we found this exceptional hotel: clean, no noisy on the apartment in the back, low price and a friendly staff....

I finally chose the Comfot Inn Midtown after extensive searching and reading many reviews on Tripadvisor and other websites. I had previously had a great stay at the Comfort Inn Manhattan but was put off by recent reviews. So the Comfort Inn Midtown. The hotel is being renovated which did not personally cause me any problems, but could be inconvenient to others. I think most of the renovation is finished now anyway. The staff are very helpful, the breakfast is good and a real plus point: bagels, donuts, toast, waffles, pastries yes, but also, fruit, cereal, yogurt, juice, eggs and hot drinks. There are two PC's for internet use, and apat from once when one guest selfishly used the PC for ages, there was always a free PC. The hotel is in an excellent location, literally around the corner from Times Square. This however means that if you have a room at the front of the hotel it is very noisy. If you are a light sleeper, ask for a room in the back. The noise from the street was incredible and constant. This is the only negative aspect. We had room 602, which was a very good size, the bathroom was big and the room was nice and comfy. I think all the rooms ending in 01 / 02 are quite big, but they are at the front. If you call ahead to request, they should be able to accommodate you.

Our family had two rooms during Thanksgiving Weekend. The rooms were small (typical NYC) but clean, very quiet, comfortable bed (upgraded to king!), recently re-decorated,big TV, spacious bathroom. Staff was delightful...welcoming and friendly. Breakfast room was small but adequate ... simple continental breakfast with fresh whole fruit and pastries. Coffee/tea available all day. Convenient to Times Sq (half a block) and subways (2 blocks). A great place to stay in NYC for a reasonable price. Nancy

The only positive comment I have about this hotel is that it was clean. The rooms were very small, I was actually very surprised at how small they were. The pictures on the website were not very accurate as far as that goes. We got a room with one queen bed and that was all that fit in the room, literally. You really had to squeeze your way around the bed, between it and the desk/chair, to get around. And the other problem was the noise, from loud water pipes in the walls every time a toilet was flushed or shower started, to room doors loudly slamming, to people scrubbing down and painting the hallway walls at 8:00 in the morning. I thought it was very rude that they would do that so early in the morning. I would have much rather spent an extra $100 or so just to get a good night's sleep. I would recommend you do the same.

Small room, but according to other reviews of comparable hotels, the room size was OK. I was still a little shocked though. Very near to Time Square, about a block away. Appears safe, even though it was located on somewhat of a dark street. Hotel staff was never off the phone, so it was hard to talk to them about much. Room was in good condition...just remodeled. Great value for a place next to Time Square for such a good price. Continental breakfast in the morning was good as well. I don't think you'll be disappointed since the price is so low!

We've just got back from staying here for 4 nights, and everything about the hotel was great. Excellent service, nothing was too much trouble, the breakfast was a great way to start the day and all the staff were very welcoming, it was like a home from home.The hotel is in an excellent location, literally 2 mins walk from Times Square, and also handy for Macey's (10min walk) and many other attractions within a short distance. The hotel inside is very clean, and modernly decorated. The room had all the amenities.. hairdryer, Iron, tea / coffee making facilities, nice big comfortable bed and big LCD TV. The smaller touches, such as complimentary internet access and free newspapers in reception were also available. Next time we go to New York we will definately stay here again.. We'd like to thank all the hotel staff for making our stay as enjoyable and comfortable as it was. Hope to see them all again next year (money permitting!!).

My fiance and I stayed here for 5 nights, during a very hot May!It was located in a fantasic place, couldn't ask to be nearer to anything! 3 - 5min walk to Macy's and round the corner to the Empire State. Every night we walked about 10-15mins up Broadway to Time Square - it was easy and so safe. The rooms, yes are a little dated, but as it is just a base at the end of the day, we weren't too bothered! Big room with small ensuite. TV with cable, hairdyer etc - what you would expect.I advise anyone to plan ahead before going to New York. We pre-booked our tickets for the Statue of Liberty Ferry at home before we left, and therefore didn't have to queue! We did go early in the morning however! Also I advise you to be at the Empire State for 8am - as the queues become huge and I'm sure you don't want to spend half your holiday stuck in one!We also pre-booked a helicopter flight across the city - which was fantastic! Yes, you can take your own cameras - dispite some reviews! The breakfast at the hotel was typically 'American' and sugary! But hey, it was lovely! Different selection of doughnuts, bagels with cream cheese, various cereals, juice, eggs. This was an added bonus, as most NYC hotels don't include breakfast in their tariff. We only had one quibble with the hotel....on our last night we had just come back from Bubba Gump Restaurant on TImes Square (highly reccommend it) and as we entered the room a mouse ran across the floor - understandable in these older buildings. But I was not going to sleep in a room where the mouse had run under the bed!!!We asked at reception to be moved they were fine about it. However the first room they moved us to was a smoking room (it stank) and the beds were unmade. SO they moved us to another room. Still a bit smokey though. It was our last night so we didn't care. Another things was the VERY RUDE bell boy! We encountered him within the 1st 10minutes of or stay - he grabs your bags like a leach!We knew tipping was a big thing in NY, but we only had a dollar bill and a 50! So I gave him the dollar bill....He responded, not wth a kind thankyou - but....I wouldn't even give a Mexcian that!! I thought..How rude and racist! I should have taken it back off him, he was lucky to get anything! We're not stingy, but we didn't think we'd be rudely put upon within our first 10 minutes!! We stayed away form him on our way home, we carried our own bags! Rude Man!!However, I would recommend the hotel, due to its location and value for money. Staff were friendly on the counter, but stay away from the bell boy!!!!

We stayed in a newly renovated room. It was a bit crowded with furniture, but very well thought-out and attractive. The bathroom was larger than expected. Our window faced an air-shaft, so it was very quiet. The soundproofing between rooms also seemed to be good. The breakfast was just fine. We paid between $304 and $395 per night, depending on the night of the week. The location is ideal for theater-going and close to several subway stops. Overall, this hotel exceeded my expectations. I'd stay there again.

The price was right. Everything was small but that didn't matter since it was just a place to sleep. We requested a queen size bed and got a king size. The staff was very friendly. The biggest problem was the elevator: small, slow, and sometimes broken. And there was only one for service and patrons.

I chose this hotel for the reasonable price during high season after reading the many reviews here. We were only in NY for one night and had theater tickets and chose to stay in TS. Overall, we were pleased with our experience. Staff were all very friendly and helpful. Thank you! My only complaint, and it's a big one for me, was that even though the hotel is a non-smoking one our room had a strong smoke smell. The non-smoking aspect is a major one when I book any hotel. This hotel was booked so we were stuck. Also, coincidently, in our "wing" ours was the only door that didn't have a non-smoking sign on the outside. The room was small but we expected that. The carpet was not too clean, worn in parts, and had cigarette burns. The bathroom was nice & roomy and clean. Extra large sink was a nice touch. The bed was okay to sleep in. The hotel was extremely quiet which is also a plus. There was a coffee maker, iron & ironing board. Closet was very short which worked ok for us but from the rod to floor was only about 4 feet. The free continental breakfast is an added benefit. For a longer stay, I would not have been comfortable here but for our short stay, it was fine.

This is a good quality hotel located just off Times Square. Some rooms are currently been renovated but all are too a good standard (considering some floors were being renovated you never heard any noise!). Some rooms are small but if you are like us you will only be in them when going to sleep!The hotel is on a quiet road off Times Square, it seems it is not one of the main access streets so the traffic was quite quiet.There is continental breakfast available till 10am which meant we could fill up on food before heading out for the day. Rooms are cleaned every day & towels are replaced.All the staff were friendly & there was tea & coffee, internet access and a small gym available free of charge all day.If you are looking for a clean, well maintained hotel not far from the action this hotel is for you.

My stay at the Comfort Inn was from Sept 30- Oct 4, 2007. I was not expecting luxury as it is one of a few reasonably priced ($240/night) near Times Square, but now that I’ve returned, I would have been so disappointed if I’d missed this gem!To say the location is perfect is an understatement. The hotel is ½ block from Broadway and 1 ½ blocks from Times Square, one block from a subway, and two blocks from “restaurant row.” There is also a stop for the “hop on/hop off” bus tours and city buses at the corner (less than one minute walk). You are within a five minute walk to many of the major attractions (MTV studios, NBC, Rockefeller, all Broadway theatres, 42nd Street, etc). With that said, the hotel is actually very quiet and secluded (though I always felt safe, no matter what time of the day or night), tucked away from the hustle and bustle half a block away.The hotel itself was very nice. The staff is so friendly and helpful, and always greets you with kindness when you enter the lobby. My room (and my companion's room as well) was immaculately clean, spacious by New York standards, nicely decorated with kind of “funky” prints, and it has in-room coffee and tea (such a plus, and one lacking from the rooms at other hotels in the immediate area with rates upwards of $600/night). The bed and linens were very clean, and though the mattress was too hard for my personal taste, my travelling companion thought it was perfect. Continental breakfast is also served from 7-10 am and is included in the price of your room.The Comfort Inn was a perfect home base for all my travels in New York, and I hope to stay there each time I return. Please feel free to e-mail me if you have any questions!

Stayed 9 days 24 Sept-3 Oct 2007. In summary, the hotel is in a good central location, is well kept and is good value compared to other hotels. We chose this hotel from the reviews and were not disappointed. The hotel is well decorated and kept clean & the complimentary breakfast helped every day get off to a good start. The hotel location is great, on a relatively quiet side street near to everything (theatres, restaurants, 5th avenue shops, Central Park, Bryant Park & many museums & galleries. We walked to most places easily as NY is flat. For our first few days we did the 'hop on and off' Gray Line bus tours and found this was a great way to get to know the city - the tour guides commentaries were informative & entertaining.At the hotel we were given a large front (street) facing room on arrival. We found this a bit noisy (when the garbage was collected in the morning) so mentioned this to reception on the following morning. They were happy to organise an immediate move to a room which was totally quiet (as the staff had promised). It was smaller than the front room but we were very happy with it as the room had recently been refurbished and was really nice. The view from the window was of an adjacent wall - but we didn't care as the room was our base to sleep. During the day and the evenings we were living in New York, not the hotel room!

This place is only 1 block from Times Square, Rockefeller and several subway lines. Staff were very professional, and many were same staff from our stay 2 years before-they must like it too! Breakfast was included and was an excellent start to the day. Room is small, as most NYC rooms are, but has been redone since our last stay and is very nice, and still very clean. And the mature rate price was unbeatable for Times Square location.

My husband and I stayed at the Comfort In Midtown from Sep. 21st to Sep. 23. We arrived with no problem or lineup at the hotel. we were able to go to our room immediately. The front desk clerk (Jevanni) (not sure of the spelling) was excellen and efficient. We were on the 8th floor in room 800. The elevator is small....actually the entire hotel is small in stature. It's very narrow and tall. Our room was small but well appointed. It had a queen bed with one end table and a desk. There was a tv, a window w/ AC and a bathroom. There was an ironing board and iron and a hairdryer. The room was exceptionally clean! The bed was very comfortable. I have never slept so well in a hotel before. I don't think it was all the bed I think it also had something to do with the amount of walking we did on Friday and Saturday! The view we had was of a brick wall but other than the initial first few minutes of being in the room we never really needed to look out side because we were...well....outside ourselves. The bathroom was spotless and once we let the water run a bit in the a.m. the hot water was plentiful. If you are undecided about staying at this hotel and you need a few reasons to tip the scale in favour of it then here are some:1-Continental breakfast!!!! Do not underestimate the value of not having to think about the first meal of the day. This was such a nice feature, you get up and eat and you're off to see NYC. The bagels were really really fresh and delicious too.2-Staff, they were very friendly and helpful!3-Proximity to Times Square, Rockefeller Centre, Broadway Shows are literally on your doorstep.4-Cleanliness5-Efficient If you are there for a weekend definetly use the hop on/off tours by grayline. You can't miss them there are ticket sellers on every corner in Times Square.Hope this helps!

The last time I was in Manhattan (last summer), I stayed in Econo Lodge Times Square (W 47th St.). It was an excellent value at under $150 per night. I planned to stay there again this year; however, when I checked the price for this year's trip, I was astounded to see that the price had doubled, so I looked at other options. I ended up staying at Comfort Inn Midtown, which was just a couple of blocks away and was now practically the same price as the Econo Lodge. (I paid $240-$270 for each of the 3 nights I stayed--Saturday, Sunday, Monday.)I was pleasantly surprised because Comfort Inn's bedrooms were twice as large, as was the bathroom. In addition, unlike the Econo Lodge, the Comfort Inn had an exercise room and an office with 2 computers; it also had a larger lobby and more soda machines. The breakfast was also a bit better. It included cereal, donuts, bagles, bananas, apples, mixed nuts, dried cranberries and white raisins, frozen waffles, yogurt, boiled eggs, coffee, juice, cappuccino, and even Red Bull (regular and sugar free). The location is ideal, as it is just a few blocks from the main activities in Midtown Manhattan, including Broadway, Times Square, 42nd Steet, Rockefeller Center, 5th Ave, and the Museum of Modern Art. Although it is just a few hundred feet from the busiest part of Manhattan (the real core of the Big Apple), it is not excessively loud, because it is half a block off of the main strip. The view is not great. In fact, the only window in our room overlooked a tiny enclosed court; the only thing you could see were the windows of other people's rooms. The staff was generally friendly and helpful. I forgot to bring shaving cream. I inquired at the front desk if they had any. The woman at first said they had none. But, as I was walking away, she took the extra step of asking the man who is apparently in charge of supplies (he supplies the breakfast area, for example) if he knew of any. He not only found me a travel-sized shaving cream but even a couple of razors (which I didn't even ask for). They also went out of their way to help me arrange the receipts for a complicated payment arrangement that I had.Granted, this is not the Marriott Marquis (which is literally right across the street), but, then again, it costs only about half as much as the Marriott. Unless you are planning to spend a lot of time in your room while in Manhattan (who does that anyway?), choose this hotel as a great mid-level hotel. If you are on a tight budget, check the rates at the Econo Lodge first, but, unless it is substantially cheaper (at least $50-$100 cheaper), go ahead and book at the Comfort Inn because it is much roomier and has many more amenities.
Great location, good and clean hotel. I can warmly recommend this hotel, it hosts all the essentials and nothing elseTake care and safe travel! Behind the digital goose pen, /Chris

I stayed at this hotel 11th - 16th Aug 2007. I didn't know what to expect due to the different reviews but was pleasantly surprised. We stayed in room 902 which had obviously been redecorated and had new furniture. It was really lovely. The free breakfast consisted of cereal, toast, bagels, danish pastry, yogurts and fruit. A good start to the day!The hotel staff are very friendly and the free internet in the lobby was a great help for when we wanted to look things up.New York is a fantastic place, we loved it but now need a holiday to get over it!!!Take comfortable shoes, you will walk for miles. The subway is handy and cheap compared to the UK underground.Top of the Rockfeller is a must at night, it's an amazing sight and you can have your photo done with the empire state building in the background. Enjoy your trip!

This is our second trip to NYC where we used this hotel. Once again, we come away strongly recommending the Comfort Inn.We arrived for a two night stay in late July. We had booked the room at least six months in advance for $166 per night using the Choice Hotels website, under the "internet users" special rate. We were placed in one of the newly refurbished rooms on the 9th floor. The good: LOCATION(!), clean, new furnishings, great size (for a NYC hotel room), quiet (with regard to other hotel guests.) The bad: since we were on the front of the hotel, the noise from the garbage trucks seemed to go on all night long, the window air conditioner was quite loud (although, it does help drown out the garbage trucks!), the elevator is (still) quite slow, which was not a real big problem because the hotel was not anywhere near 100% occupied for our two nights.The staff, as before, was fabulous. What amazed me is that I remembered most of the staff from my visit here two years earlier. I did not expect that the same people would be working the front desk, the bellman positions, etc. This is the kind of stability that says something about a little hotel such as this.As before, is it the Marriot Marquis? No, that's one block to the West! It's also $400 bucks a night. I would much rather use the extra $200 per night and go out and DO something in NYC with that money. Please feel free to contact me with any questions you have about this property.

We have stayed at this hotel for years for its location and earlier affordibility. Last time we went, we were pleasantly surpised to see the upgrades and were told they were also replacing the furniture. Prices had increased a bit, but it was still reasonable.We came home and I was just about to plan our next trip. Much to our DISAPPOINTMENT, we now find that the prices have DOUBLED! We won't be coming back!

We stayed at this Comfort Inn and we were very pleased with it. It is in a great location....Right in Times Square. However it was very quiet. No street noises. The rooms were on the small side but nicely kept and very clean. The free breakfast was great and we appreciated the 24 hour access to coffee, tea , a microwave and the internet with a printer. Most appreciated was the very helpful and extremely nice staff . The General Manager,the people on the front desk , housekeeping, the bellmen were all friendly . They made our stay very nice. Also for a New York hotel in that area the rate was very reasonable. I would stay there again for sure.

We spent one night here after going to a baseball game at Yankee Stadium and before heading on a longer trip. The hotel is very close to Times Square, so it is right in the heart of midtown Manhattan. Our room was clean and comfortable. It was small, but considering the location and price, no complaints there. The wireless Internet was easy, fast, and reliable. The only downsides we had were with checkin. We drove in and needed to unload and park. We found the hotel, but the unloading area was full and there's no other parking on the street. We called the front desk to see if we could just park and they said to come to the front to unload anyway. After going around the block (which is a 15-20 minute undertaking in NYC), we were able to park in front. We then found that the hotel was short staffed and rooms were just being cleaned. They said 15 minutes, so I decided we'd park in the garage with the hotel rate and check in after that. Of course, the entrance to the garage was just a bit in the wrong direction on 46th. So around the block again for 20 minutes to the garage. When we got back to the front desk, the room was still not ready (he said 15 minutes again) but offered to take our bags so we could go look around. But before we got a chance to leave, good news, the room was ready so we went up. So really, my only complaint is that the desk should have told us in the first place where to park to avoid the two trips around the block. But beyond all of that, we had a great experience and would gladly stay here again.

We enjoyed our brief stay at this hotel. It's well-located in the heart of midtown and the price, while somewhat expensive, was excellent compared to comparable hotels in Manhattan. There is a 24-hour exercise room and free continental breakfast available. The front desk staff was exceptionally pleasant -- when I casually mentioned that it was my birthday, the guy at the desk ran to the back office and handed me a promotional package of various samples (gum, lotion, razor, etc.) as a present. The hallways are small and cramped, but the room was a good size (especially for New York) and was clean. Only a few minor complaints - all of the bedding, other than the pillowcases, was stiff and scratchy. Also, the air conditioner (a window unit) was somewhat weak. We turned it on to full blast at nine o'clock at night and the room was still pretty warm 3 hours later, although it was cool by morning. These are pretty minor quibbles, though. Overall, I think this hotel is a great value for New York.

Hi I'm from the UK and visited NY as a tourist for a week. I liked the Comfort Inn Midtown because the location is excellent. Its half a block away from the middle of Times Square, you can see the neon signs from the front door of the hotel, so you are already in the heart of the tourist area and subway links. The hotel was clean and the staff were friendly. There are a couple of computers on the ground floor with free internet access which was ace and there is a tiny gym room with a couple of treadmills too which is a nice touch. Though I didn't see anyone using the gym, not surprising with downtown NY just outside. There was free breakfast in mornings in the little dining room off the lobby. I ate so much that I wouldn't get hungry again until about 3pm, and no one cared which is great. OK the view from my room was rubbish, my key card kept failing and there is only one lift for the entire hotel but for the price its pretty cool. I'd definately go back and I recommend it to others. Thanks for reading!

I stayed in this hotel in March for a professional conference because I couldn't afford the conference hotel (Hilton) without a roommate. The rooms at Comfort Inn are small, but perfect for one person or for a couple. The best part about this hotel is its location. You look outside the front lobby and you are literally looking right at Times Square less than a block away. It's also within easy walking distance of the north part of Midtown like Rockefeller Center. My first experience upon check-in was not positive, but the experience improved significantly. The TV in my first room did not receive CBS and March Madness was in full swing. They changed me to another room and the air conditioner did not work. It was March and chilly, but I need air to sleep. The maintenance man was ready to send me to another hotel but the manager took care of me. Third time's the charm and the third room was great. Aside from the small room size, the only other drawbacks were that the shower was extremely small -- not to be disrespectful, but an overweight person could not use the shower -- and the hotel seems older with old carpet, etc. But everything did seem clean, which is more important to me than new.The positives far outweight the negatives. The staff seemed friendly (especially by New York standards) and willing to help. The breakfast room offered a free continental breakfast. Two days I sat down and had toast, yogurt, fruit, etc., and two days I grabbed a muffin and coffee and headed out the door. Both ways saved me at least $10 to $15 a day.The other nice freebie is Internet service. There are two computers and a printer. I was able to check my e-mail every day and print my boarding pass for my departing flight. People were friendly and willing to share -- no one hogged a computer for hours. We did our business and moved on. There was also a treadmill but I was too lazy to use it.Overall, you CANNOT GO WRONG with this hotel if you want to be close to the action but not close to the price of most New York hotels. I absolutely recommend it.

The hotel is at the Times Square area, so everything is walking distance, lots of restaurants available but would recommend to venture out of midtown to get a better bargain for your money. The street it wsa on is called Litle Brazil, so lots of Spanish style restaurants which were good.Hotel itself was okay for our budget, rooms just about fit the queen size bed. Bathroom was very clean. My only inconvenience was airconditioning, it was not adequate, it was old and obsolete. It did not cool the room enough and was very noisy. It was cooler in the lobby than the room.Thank goodness we only stayed for one night. The staff was friendly. Hotel provided continental breakfast.

What a disappointment! This well located Midtown Manhattan Comfort Inn had a nice facade - clean lobby, breakfast area, nice computer room and small exercise room. But once off the lobby area it all went downhill fast.The room we stayed in on the 5th floor was very small and cramped. The TV armoir was so close to the beds and bathroom door it made manuvering around it at night a hazard. The standard mini coffee maker was located in the bathroom - above the toilet no less! Talk about an unappetizing and unsanitary place to be making coffee - by the john.The rug was so stained and soiled I wore my socks or shoes the entire time we were there.The bedspreads were worn to the point of being almost threadbare. The sheets were standard white, with the added bonus of a few ink or who knows what stains on them that had not come out in the wash.As I was in the manager's office complaining, I realized that her office was just as bad! The carpet was stained, her desk a mess and she offered no remedy or compensation. She did say that the upper floors of the hotel were undergoing renovations and that the 5th floor and below really needed it too.Other than the location and pleasant front desk staff, we were not pleased with this Comfort Inn. I would not recommend staying there.By the way, the cost of this room for one night, on a Monday mid May was well over 200 dollars.

A surprisingly quiet location just a block away from all the hustle and bustle of New York city. There was some initial misunderstanding on the room rates - I was quoted the AAA rate but when I arrived I was presented with the regular rate - but it was sorted out. Room size is decent for New York city, bathroom is clean. Be assured that you can get a good night of sleep here.

I was a bit worried about how the hotel would be but im glad i listened to all the positive reviews. It was absolutely fine! For one of the cheaper hotels in NY, we felt it had everything we needed and the location was perfect for seeing everything and a few minutes walk to the restaurants/shows in Times Square. Our Queen room on the 2nd floor was clean and spacious, with tea/coffee facilities, iron, hairdryer, and a good size bathroom. Air conditioning was a bit loud but it worked! Having free breakfast (if we wanted it) and free internet access was great! And the reception staff were very helpful and friendly (and happy to change peoples rooms if they wanted to). Couldnt really fault the place! Would definitely reccommend!
Fantastic location - just blocks from Broadway shows, Times Square. Quite reasonable for the location. Room was clean and larger than most NY hotel rooms. I will definitely stay here again!

A block off Times Square, this is a great location for theatre goers. Plenty going on in the neighborhood. Lobby was not bad, with breakfast area, free internet and printer, exercise room. As a business traveler I was given a small bag with generous sample sizes of toiletries and snacks. Rooms were New York city small, with a small closet although a decent sized bathroom. Room had coffee maker, clock radio, and a TV that needed some adjustment. The air conditioning is supplied by a room unit that can be noisy for some, but the outflow was blocked by the drapes which were tricky to close. The staff were friendly, knowledgable. Reports of noise in other reviews did not materialize except for some door slamming. With prices sky high in Manhattan the Comfort Inn offers a reasonably priced stay although in other cities $250 would get you five star accommodations.

I won't repeat what others have said about this hotel, but I highly recommend it for anyone who would like to stay near Times Square. It is a short 5 min walk from the closest subway station (both the Times Square one and the 42nd blue line which is a straight connect to the AirTrain Jamaica station). Although not a glamourous hotel, it met our basic needs. Clean room, clean bathroom, and a free continental breakfast. Really, you don't need much more when you're mostly wandering in NYC.Definitely will come back to this hotel the next time we visit NYC.

I just came back from a very nice experience at the Comfort Inn Midtown. I stayed in a standard room with a queen-size bed and had plenty of room. The room, bathroom, bed linens, et al were very clean. I was on the fourth floor in the front of the hotel, so I could hear some street noise at night, but it wasn't excessive and it didn't keep me awake.The location was FABULOUS...if you love Broadway shows, it's the best. It was right down the street from the TKTS stand and within easy walking distance of the shows.Best of all was the attitude of the staff. The check-in staff was friendly, there was a gentleman who was wonderful about little courtesies like opening the elevator when he saw you coming, and the desk staff was nice about answering questions, giving directions, etc. I loved being able to check my e-mail, and the continental breakfast in the morning was a simple but tasty way to start the day.This is a budget hotel, but I found the overall quality, services, and friendliness to be much better than other budget places where I've stayed. The Comfort Inn Midtown enhanced my trip to Manhattan, and I'll be back!

My wife and I stayed here for four nights in March 2007 and had a most pleasant experience. We have stayed in many Comfort Inns across the States and although the rooms here are smaller the double room we got was perfectly adequate, bed was comfortable and everything was spotless. Nice touch is the goody bag on arrival. Staff most pleasant and helpful. Breakfast was excellent with a good choice and plentiful. Also very nice clientelle. Approximately 100 yds. from Times Square-you won't get better location. Also felt very safe although could say this for anywhere we visited. For a nice drink Rosie O'Gradys is two doors away and open late. It's friendly and accommodating. O'Briens across the road is much smaller, wasn't to our taste and the drink prices were steep by comparison with most bars we visited. O'Flahertys on East 46th. Street is more of an old style bar, has music every night and is worth a visit if you don't mind a bit of a walk. For good food at reasonable prices, lunch specials and very reasonable drink prices (pint of Bud for $3) try McAnnas to the left as you exit the hotel- about two blocks. Excellent fish and chips for $7.95. We absolutely loved New York and and can't wait to visit again. Would have no hesitation in staying at the Comfort again and would recommend to anyone in particular first time visitors.

This is seriously THE BEST location that money can buy in Midtown Manhattan. We paid around $170 per night for the hotel. They also will give you a AAA discount (10% off). The Comfort Inn Midtown is less than 1/2 block from the center of Times Square. Granted, it's not a luxury hotel, but it is a clean, decent place to sleep at night. And besides, that's what a hotel is for anyways. You don't spend that much time there. The room was small, as is expected for NY. The bed is decent. There was no view, but this is also expected since Manhattan is full of skyscrapers to block the views. The plus is that there's free continental breakfast in the morning and free internet. The front desk staff was very curtious and polite. The 1/2 price ticket booth (for musicals and plays) is 1/2 block away. The hotel is also about 1 block from 5th Avenue (with all the famous shopping). Manhattan has a great subway system. The subway stop is less than 1 block away from the hotel. It's within walking distance to most of the theaters, Rockefeller Center, Macy's, We saw Doubt (a play) and it was excellent. We took the subway everywhere and saw just about everything there was to see in Manhattan.

Myself and my three friends decided to go for four nights and five days to New York City for spring break. As University students, we don't exactly have a lot of cash to spend on accomodations or transportation, so we decided to stay somewhere affordable and close to Times Square. Those two aspects of this hotel is pretty much where the positives end.I may be a little bit biased as I am used to travelling with my family, and we tend to stay at luxury hotels when we go away. However, I have stayed with friends at Comfort Inns before, several times actually, and I have never been as unpleasantly surprised as I was with this particular one. The room was small. When I say it was small, I mean small even by New York City standards. The two double beds were practically touching and I couldn't even pull my suitcase from one side of the room to the other. The bathroom was a tub and a sink, and it was freezing cold. The heater was a very noisy window unit and the temperature did not stay consistent.The main hallway was nice, but it is decieving. We stayed on the fourth floor, and the rooms were so close to each other that we could hear everything that was going on in the room next to us VERY clearly. On the last two nights that we were there there was a couple across the hall that seemed to be filming rather innapropriate amateur movies quite unabashadly, and with the door to their room wide open. We called the front desk, but no one did anything and the nonsense went on until about 3AM, when they finally shut their door.Room service was fine. The pillows were quite lumpy, the beds were hard and the sheets were clean, but very old and faded. We didn't have any problems with our maid service. Due to our familiarity with luxury hotels, we often lef cash sitting on the desk and bedside tables by accident, but it was always there when we returned at night.Breakfast was wonderful. it was actually oddly out of place in the otherwise budget hotel. There was fresh coffee, a cappuccino machine, bagels, muffins, several types of cereal, waffles, a toaster and fresh fruit. They also provided Red Bull free of charge every morning, which I found quite nice. I'm not a breakfast eater, but I did find myself waking up specifically so I could go down for some in the mornings.I probably would have returned to stay if I hadn't been so insulted by the manager when we checked out. The staff had, up until this point been very very friendly. The breakfast attendant did not speak any english, but he was always smiling, the maids were friendly and very accomodating, the front desk attendant was very nice and I had a good chat with him almost every night. However, the manager, a woman whose name I can't remember, was very rude. When we were checking out we noticed that there was a long distance phone call on our bill for $10. We looked up the area code and it was a call to Quebec. None of us had made a phonecall from the room, we all used our cell phones. At one point we tried to order pizza, but couldn't even get the room phone to work. Despite our best efforts, we couldn't even get the manager to care or check into it. She just kept shrugging it off and telling us we had to pay. I mean, it was only $10. We insisted on talking to someone else, but she told us there simply was no one else, and then announced that she had to go home as her shift was over.If you want something cheap and in a good location and you don't mind cramped rooms, loud noises and pornographers, you should be fine. I recommend the breakfast.

I will be eternally grateful to the Comfort Inn Midtown for rescuing us from the horror of the Murray Hill Inn (where we had originally booked for five nights but left after two for various reasons - refer my review for that hotel).So, maybe I was wearing rose-coloured glasses but the CIM seemed like an oasis to us! Less than one minute's walk from Times Square, and just a couple of blocks from Fifth Avenue, the location is fantastic. The complimentary breakfast is basic but fresh (bagels, juice, tea/coffee/red bull, yoghurt, cereals), and it's great to have free access to the internet. The staff on the front desk take some prompting to get their attention.Our room was very spacious by NYC standards also with a large bathroom including a bath. All very clean and tidy. The lift is small, slow and there's just one, but better than none at all. (Murray Hill Inn take note.)Highly recommended!

A friend and I booked this hotel pretty last minute. We had searched for a few days to find a hotel that had a good price, a good location, and 2 double beds (most things you book online, you can't request this). I chanced upon this one, and am so glad!It's close enough to Broadway / Times Square that you can walk to all the shows, yet in enough off 6th Ave to be quiet at night. We (Two twenty-something women) felt very safe walking in the area, and to and from the hotel at night. It is also close to the subway, which we also used (though forgot a few times to watch for uptown/downtown direction...whoops!).The hotel was great. All staff were friendly and helpful, and check-in and out was done in a matter of minutes. I called the hotel directly to book and received the exact room I wanted. I then was able to recieve a 10% discount by presenting my AAA card upon arrival. This made it cheaper than anything we found online.  We stayed in room 608--request it if you are also looking for a 2 double bed room. The closet was on the small side, but we had no trouble with having enough space for the 2 of us. People complained in other reviews about having a room in the back, with a view of a building, but honestly, it was fine--we heard no noise outside! Even if you had a room at the front of the hotel, you'd only see the building across the street, and it would probably be noisy at night! You could hear people opening/closing doors in our section of the hall (7 or 8 rooms) but not so much that we were disturbed during the night.I guess if there were more than 2 people there, things could be a little tight, but it's doable. The hotel was clean and comfortable. The free breakfast was great (from 7 to 10 am), bagels, cereal, coffee, juice, yogurt, toast--helped us save a few bucks. The elevator is small, so you might have to wait to go up, but really, who cares? There are two computers, which were handy for checking show prices & mapping places we wanted to go. You might have to wait a few minutes if other guests are there, but no big deal. Hallways are narrow, as they are in many hotels. Really, it was a very decent hotel for a fabulous price. We are highly recommending it to friends and family in the future...Just a side note, if you are going to a broadway show & want cheap tickets: Many shows have last minute ticket lotteries a few hours ahead of show time. These tickets are under $30 each and are usually for the front row. You can hope your name is pulled and get 2 tix per name. However, lotteries are open for up to 30 min...and people come from nowhere to put their name in! Other shows have "rush" tickets where the first 30 or so people in line can get up to 2 tix per person. The Disney ones specify that these are for students, but others (Color Purple, Chicago, etc.) are just first come, first served; each person in line gets 2 tix. Just do a round of the ticket offices for shows you want to see; ask them what time to get there for lotteries/RUSH tix and try that first!WORTH IT TO CHECK OUT BEFORE GOING TO TKTS (which cost 60 - 100 dollars (though maybe better seats).

Me and my family stayed here for 5 nights in a 2 double bedded room. The room was clean and fresh towels provided everyday. The room was fairly small for 4 people but was more than sufficient considering it was only used as a base. The bathroom was fairly cold but you only use it for a short time so no real problem once the shower was used. The breakfast was more than adequate with a selection of bagels, pastries, yogurts, cereal, fruit e.t.cThe location is great and if you want a drink in the evening there was a bar (rosie o'grady) just along the road that had no problem with our 2 sons being allowed in (ages 16 and 13)So all in all a decent room for the fairly inexpensive rate and i would use them again if I ever returned to NYC

Well, It was my first time not only in New York but in the USA and I have to say that the location of the hotel is great. Me and my boyfriend had a nice experience in this place; Its clean and the employees were really kind. We didnt had a room with a nice view, but a very quiet room (except by the heater, seems little old) We were little concerned about security, but nothing happened at the end. Basic breakfast its like that: basic, and its served in a small saloon, anyway it was clean and enough to start our walks throw New York. If I have to repeat, I will do it without doubts. The price related to the quality of the place its more than fair.

I stayed 3 nights at this hotel which was in a wonderful location and reasonably priced. I would never stay there again because of the noise though. The room doors are heavy and close loud and hard. I tried to respect my neighbors, but they didn't do the same for me. I was awakened constantly during the night. I stayed up until 12:30 a.m., but others around me were up later and every time someone closed their door it woke me up and shook the room. The noise would start up again around 6:30 a.m. as people left their rooms. I have never heard hotel room doors close so loudly. Waking up constantly because of this ruined this hotel for me. There were other negatives such as the room phone that worked the first day, but not the other two days. The weather was very cold while I was there, and at night I about froze in the bed. The blankets were tissue thin. I slept with a sweater over my pajamas. Unless I couldn't find it, I don't think there was any way to control the heat in the room. There was a window air conditioner, but for heat I was at the hotel's mercy. The room seemed clean until I pulled the bedsheets back at midnight on the first night and saw a semen stain. Despite all of this, I have to admit that the location was terrific and the staff that I encountered were delightful. They were all pleasant and very friendly. The bathroom was large and the water pressure great with plenty of hot water. I really liked the people that worked there, but I just wouldn't go back primarily because of the loud room doors.

My 9 year old daughter and I stayed here for 4 days last week. I was a little concerned about safety, but my mind was put at ease by the other reviews. The staff was so nice to us and really went out of their way to make us feel welcome. We were even given a "goody bag" upon arrival, which was the coolest thing for my daughter! Our room was on the small side, but was large enough for 2 twin beds, a desk, entertainment center and our luggage. The bathroom was clean and even had a hair dryer, coffee maker and window shelf for all of things. The BEST thing about this hotel is the location. You are literally steps away from Times Square! We walked everywhere (Today Show, shopping on Fifth Ave. and all Broadway shows). For the price, you can not go wrong here. If you are going to New York to sit in a big expensive hotel room, then you are going for the wrong reasons!! We will stay at this location on all of our future trips and will highly recommend it to our family and friends.

As so many of the reviews here will tell you, this hotel benefits from a superb location, just off Times Square in NYC. Literally steps away from the action and inside the New Year celebrations police cordon when we stayed there in 2006/7.Accomodation is, unfortunately, a little less glamorous. Think tired Travelodge and you'll have the idea. Our room was small (about 11 feet square) with a view of the next building. You could just about see the sky if you peered up between the buildings. Our room on the 3rd floor was quiet, even on New Years Eve, an important plus for a city centre hotel!Despite it's slightly tired appearance, the hotel had a good continental breakfast included and the desk staff were helpful and polite. Add that to complimentary gym and internet access (2 PCs) and you have a good budget package, considering the location.In short, don't expect too much and you won't be dissapointed.

Four of us went to Manhattan in Dec of 2006. I checked Trip Advisor for reviews, and the ratings given were very reliable. The location of this hotel is perfect for Time Square area. The room was not overly small considering size of most NYC rooms. I felt that it was more than adequate for 2 people. Hotel Staff very helpful and courteous. The room was clean and comfortable. We had a room on the 7th floor front view. The other couple with us had a side room. Both rooms OK, but I believe the room with the front view had a little more room than the side room. Only one elevator in hotel, but it really was not a major problem. Breakfast room a little small, but my advice is don't be in a hurry, give yourself enough time, wait your turn for a seat and you will enjoy a typical continental breakfast for free. I have been in many hotels in NYC including Hilton New York, Rennaissance Time Square, Millenium Broadway, and rate this hotel as one I would definetely stay at again, because of value pricing.

Based on the price we knew this would not be a luxury hotel but was just looking for something clean and safe. The room was very basic but clean. The day after we checked in my camera was stolen out of my suit case and my daughters coat pockets were gone through as well. We reported this to the manager who indicated our maid was only employed with them one week. The manager did not follow up with us as promised. We spoke with another occupant who had 2 cameras stolen from their room the same day. When they asked the hotel if any other cameras had been reported missing they were told no, which was not true. We were not advised to fill out an incident report and were discouraged from contacting the police. So for the rest of our stay we had no maid service because of concern about additional items being stolen. There is 1 ice machine and it was broken half the time we were there. Several of the hotel employees were very friendly and nice, unfortunately the theft and lack of candor and appropriate followup with the management really tainted our stay. I would not recommend staying here. The cost savings with this hotel will be spent to replace my camera that was stolen out of my suitcase.

LOCATION! LOCATION! LOCATION! This is so important, but when it is coupled with great staff and excellent cleanliness it means so much more. Good continental selectional for breakfast. Our room on the 3rd floor faced a brick wall but we just kept the shades drawn , no problem as we were out all day!!Only 2 doors away from Rosie O Gradys, good food and craic (oh, by the way thats Irish for great conversation and laughter) Forgot to mention on arrival you get a welcome bag per person with lots of little goodies included, how many hotels do this??. If you book tickets for the Greyline bus at reception you get $3 off per person Will definately stay here again!!

I have stayed at this hotel twice in the last 2 months. Five nights in October and four nights in November and was very impressed with this hotel. It is in a great location (steps to Times Square) and the staff are very helpful and friendly. The beds are very comfortable and the breakfast is excellent. The price and location are difficult to beat. The rooms are very clean. The staff also bend over backwards to arrange shuttles to the airport and to provide tourist information. Would highly recommend this hotel to anyone travelling to NYC.

My wife and I stayed here for one night while we were in New York to see some shows. While we didn't have to pay full price for our room due to points earned on a credit card affinity program, we would nonetheless definetely consider staying here next time we're in New York City. This hotel isn't fancy, certainly, but it has everything you would want for a comfortable stay. The front desk staff is exceptionally friendly and helpful for an establishment of this sort. The room is small, and a "real" window with a view of something beside the ventilation shaft would have been nice, but everything was extremely clean and well maintained. The bathroom was large and well-supplied. The television set, air conditioning, coffee maker, and clock radio worked fine, and seemed quite new. Indeed, the whole room seems to have been updated and refurbished faily recently. There was even an extra pillow for both of us! There was a nice complimentary continental breakfast, and an excercise room and internet room (which we did not use). For a hotel at this level, you really couldn't expect more. A great location as well; I couldn't believe how close Times Square was! The $23 special rate for overnight parking (in a very modern garage across the street) was quite reasonablr, as well, for New York (about half what it would have cost otherwise).

I really liked the place, abit dated in decor but it feels warm and doesnt have the sterile feel like alot of chain hotels have.The room service was good with comfy beds. Be warned of the Receptionist though, He's an anglophile - and loves all things British, constant refrences to the BBC's "keeping up apperences" made me laugh..... i would recommend this hotel.

We just returned from a five night stay at this hotel and while I was a little concerned whether it would be too basic, how wrong I was, yeah it is in need of some painting and modernisation but for that price and location you can;t go wrong. The staff were sooo nice and helpful, breakfast was plentiful, room was clean as was bathroom and of a fair size, the only concern I had was I overheard a few other guests complaining about the radiators in their room being noisy, we had no such problems thankfully. But what do you want for that price? Would stay again definitely if on a budget.

We stayed at the Hotel from the 21st Oct to 26th we were on the 6th floor and had no problems with the lift. The rooms were clean the staff helpfull and what a great location only a few yards from Times Square and lots of bars and restaurants to choose from. I would certainly stay there again and cant wait to return to NY.

This hotel was simple. It provided an excellent location for sightseeing, just a few paces from Times Square.The room was small, and don't expect a view. But if all you want is a clean, safe place to sleep at night, it is an excellent choice for the budget-concious traveller.The breakfast was well-stocked, with the usual selection of cereal, fruit, bread and bagels, pastries and donughts, juice, tea and coffee. Free copies of USA Today and the NY Post were available by 7am every morning.The staff were friendly and helpful without being "over the top".A great place to stay in a great location. Book it with confidence.

We stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown from 21st-25th September this year. The location of the hotel is superb being only 1/2 a block from Times Square. Our room was on the 7th floor and was quite bright. The room was larger than I expected and both the room and the bathroom were spotless. There were coffee making facilities which were replenished daily and an ironing board and iron in the room. All of the staff I had dealings with were polite and friendly. The free buffet breakfast consisted of bagels, toast, pastries, doughnuts, cereal, fruit, coffee and juice, all of which was replenished constantly. There is a complimentary fitness room with 3 cardio machines and a business room with 2 computers which offer free internet and printing. I would definitely recommend this hotel to others and would be very happy to stay here again.Footnote: Rosie O'Grady's Steak house a couple of doors down serve excellent food in a nice atmosphere, and O'Briens Irish Bar across the road is a great place for pre dinner drinks or for a night cap - very friendly!

This is a nice place and i would stay there again for sure, the elevator is broken alot and as long as you ask for a room on the highest floors available you will be able to see past the comfort inn sign they have on the from of the building!!!! also, ask for a room on the front of the hotel not the back, the back looks out onnto a alley and tltho not bad, its not fun to look out to a brick wall when you are in the CITY!!!! all the rooms on the front tho are one bed so our boys slept on the CLEAN NIC KEPT FLOOR!!! the hotel even offered us free extra blankets and pillows for us!!!! along with the room is a clean bath bigger then i planned on being in the city and all and the room was basic but great great location only 1/2 block from times square!!! check in is not overly friendly but you dont pay for that since the prices are pretty low for you where you are staying!!!!

Myself, my mother and my sister stayed in this hotel for 5 nights while on a shopping trip. It is in an excellent location and terrific value for money. Everything is within walking distance, broadway, 5th Av, Macys, Port Authority etc... Breakfast was included in the price which included bagels, cereal, pastries etc.. and the guy looking after the breakfast was great and don't forget to tip him! There was free computer and internet access...very handy. The room and ensuite were clean and tidy, and cleaned every day!!! Great choice for a trip to NY, have stayed in other hotels on other trips and none of them come close....will definitely be back!

New York City: Comfort Inn MidtownDate: Sept. 26 - 30, 2006Reviewer: Trip Advisor Member, Burlington,CanadaThis hotel provides very good value for the money. The room was $162 per night. The staff were friendly and helpful. The room was plenty large enough for 2 people. We did not spend a lot of time in the room. Most of our waking hours were spent sight seeing. The room was very clean. The only drawback was that the room faced 46th street and thus was quite noisey. My wife and I are fairly sound sleepers so this did not really bother us that much. Other rooms may be much quieter. The breakfast provided was typical of many hotels. We ate shotly after the breakfast room opened (7:00 am) and found everything satisfactory. The breakfast was as advertised. There was only on small elevator. We did not experience any long waits. We were on the 3rd floor and often walked down the stairs. The location is great. There are many restaurants nearby. Times Square is less than a block away. You can walk to many attractions such as Grand Central Station, Rockefeller Center, many theaters, Times Square and the bus tours (hop on/ hop off).This is a great place to stay. We would stay here again.

We stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown for 5 nights 9/26-10/1. We stayed here because we were on a budget and it was $179/night and the best we could find in the location. We couldn't have asked for a better hotel for the price. The hotel staff were very friendly. The continental breakfast was nice as well as the business center where we were able to check our emails and print our boarding passes for NO CHARGE! The room was pretty small but we were only there long enough to sleep so that didnt bother me. I also requsted a room away from the street so we didnt have any problems with noise. I did hear the slamming doors once in awhile but not enough to disrupt my sleep. Luckily we were on the 2nd floor, so we used the stairs the whole time. I did notice the elevator was very slow so I am glad we were on the 2nd floor. Overall, it was a fine hotel for the price and I would definitely stay here again. The location is excellent and you are close to subway stops.

We were staying in Comfort Inn Midtown, New York 4 nights before we went on a cruise. The hotel considering the price was above average, situated in the heart of Manhatten, the service in top, very friendly and I could go on praising the hotel. The only negative experience was the noise from the street, why I advice the owners to install windows with double glaser .

Hi! When I was planning my first-ever trip to New York City I really did not know where to stay and I admit the reviews that I read in Trip Advisor where the key element in order to choose the Comfort Inn Midtown. After a four-night stay my conclusion is that I agree to previous reviews in the sense that this hotel is a very good option in New York City.I do not have new things to add to the many reviews posted here, but I would like to comment my agreement on the following advantages of the Comfort Inn Midtown:Price.- Very affordable considering the hotel is closely located to Times Square.Room/bathroom cleanliness.- They were spotless in my experience.Room amenities.- No luxuries here but you find adequate space for clothes (corner closet), iron, ironing board, hairdryer, coffee maker, radio alarm & TV. Hotel amenities.- I found the free Internet access (two computers in a “business room”), complimentary breakfast, and free daily newspaper as a plus. There is also a fitness room but I did not use it; it seemed small but adequate.Location.- As it has been repeatedly noted, the hotel is close to Times Square and the Rockefeller subway station; the convenient location gives you the chance to walk and be part of many activities or to take the subway or a bus wherever you want to go.Staff.- In my experience, the maid and the breakfast room attendant were even friendlier than the front desk staff, but in general terms all of the employees are kind and attentive.On the other hand, some travelers have noticed weaknesses and noted them here; I have an opinion on the following:Slamming doors.- Yes, doors do slam, then it is a good idea to be careful when closing them.Elevator.- It is old and small indeed but no big deal; my room was in the sixth floor so I usually took the elevator and its service was functional enough.Room size.- I do not know other New York hotel’s room size, thus I lack a point of comparison; the room seemed small (I got a queen-size bed) but I do not need more space. Perhaps the rooms are too small if you travel with your family, but I did not have the chance to see a two-bed room to have an opinion on that.Temperature.- Other reviews complained of rooms being too hot… no problem in my stay, since tropical storm “Ernesto” brought rainy days to the city.As a side note, throughout the almost 250 TripAdvisor Traveler Reviews about the Comfort Inn Midtown, there are some descriptions that are actually referring to the Comfort Inn Manhattan, which is located in 35th St and has a total of 12 floors; the Comfort Inn Midtown is a smaller hotel, with a total of 9 floors (new readers of these reviews, please take this into account… any descriptions of a 12-floor hotel and two elevators are actually not referring to the Comfort Inn Midtown).Overall, I would stay in this hotel again.

I booked a night here based on the reviews here. This one really rose to the top as the best hotel under $200/night.I wanted a clean room for a night after a red-eye and didn't want to pay the $300/night that most name brand hotels were charging.Upon arrival, they weren't able to give us a room. Understandable since it was 8am. We returned after breakfast at a local diner and were again told that we couldn't get a room until 12 or 1. This is better than the standard 3-4 pm check in times, but we figured that they'd have an early check out and be able to get us in sometime sooner.We ended up killing a little time in the lobby and our patience paid off. Probably 15 minutes after 9, they were able to get us a clean room that more than met our expectations. Sure the room was small, but not unreasonably small. I'd say comparable to rooms in San Francisco or Europe. I'd stay there again and definitely feel it's worth the $100 in savings.

My wife and I stayed at the hotel on September 3, 2006. Yes, the rooms are small, but when you are in NYC how much time do you actually stay in the room? The bathroom was small as well, but again, how much room do you really need in the bathroom. Both the room, bathroom, and lobby were CLEAN. The air conditioner was a window unit that provided adequate cooling power (we like our room cool). Room ammenities included: iron and ironing board, hairdryer, and coffee pot.The location is great because it is between time square and 6th avenue.The only suggestion I would make for a person who is staying at this hotel, is to call the hotel and ask if there are any festivals going on that would block the street. We happened to be arriving during Brazil day, and could not access the street by car which required us to park 7 blocks away instead of the parking garage across the street from the hotel.OVERALL: We would def. stay in this hotel again!

My boyfriend and I stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown in the middle of July. We had read the reviews posted here and were fairly certain it would be a nice place. Turns out everyone was right! The Comfort Inn is located 1/2 a block from Times Square so the location couldn't be any better. We were right in the middle of the action! Being in the middle of all this you'd expect a lot of noise but our room was perfectly quiet - slamming doors were a little loud as some had mentioned before but not enough to wake us up. The room was small but that was fine with us because who wants to spend a lot of time in the hotel anyway... The room was also very clean and the staff was always extremely nice and helpful. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone looking to experience NY! Also, there's a subway station pretty close so getting around the city is no problem.

This hotel was better than expected. It was close to Times Square (1/2 a block away) and close to grand central station (3 blocks). The most important thing was that the rooms were clean. The bathroom was clean too! I know that other reviews said something about church bells, but we were right next to the church and didn't hear the bells. The only noisy thing was our child neighbor screaming at 11pm and then slamming the door to her room about 10 times. This is of course nothing that the hotel could have controlled. It was very convient to have free internet access (two computers) in the lobby. The free breakfast was also very nice. My fiance even used their fitness room which was very small but had a bike, treadmill, and stairmaster. The best part of this hotel was the unbeatable price of $110 per night! I would stay here again and reccommend it to my friends!Oh and we also stopped in Havanna central (right on 46th street a couple doors away from the hotel) for dinner and it was fantasitic especially the mojitos!

Nice hotel, at this price. First room offered was a single (that claimed to be a double). I could not see two 200lb people getiing into the bed. They changed our room for a better one. Main problem was the buiding work going on inside the hotel. They had completed the restyling of first four or five floors, but the work was still going on as we could see every day. Men carrying plaster board in the lifts and old units out meaning that only one of the two lifts was available most of the time. Place was dusty desoite the constant effort of the staff. Should be OK soon, I hope,

We stayed here from June 10-17, 2006. We had booked a room with a King bed and sofabed in November 2005. Due to the other comments on this site I rang the day I was checking in to be told byu the hotel they do not have king size beds with a sofabed in the same room. This made for a very uncomfortable stay for my husband, our eight year old and me in one bed. My brother-in-law slept in the other bed. We have not yet had an apology from the hotel, although we booked through Choice Hotels. Anyway, we had a room on the twelth floor and had fantastic views of both the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building. We walked the stairs most of the time, and it was great to walk the various staircases and to see the old building, including watching the mail go down the chute. Our room was always clean. The breakfast was very good each morning and the location was great for subways and walking.I would stay here again, but you need to ensure you are getting what you pay for.

I have just spent 7 nights at the Comfort Inn Midtown, New York City. I would agree that the location is one of the main selling points of this establishment. The Inn is situated a mere couple of minutes walk from Times Square and there are lots of local eateries (at various food prices and choices.) As well, it is close to the Hop On - Hop Off buses at Times Square and within walking distance to many of New York's vast sights and subway stations. The room my husband and I were allocated was very small, as was the bathroom (shower stall/toilet/washbasin). The room was clean - but do NOT expect 5 star accommodation. I rate this hotel as 2 1/2 to 3 stars. However, the hotel staff were very friendly and obliging. The room price included breakfast which was sufficient to start the day's activities (tea/coffee/juice + cereals/pastries etc/fruits). We enjoyed a great live theatre matinee show after waiting a relaltive short time for TDKT tickets (2 for the price of 1 !) The ticket selling booth was located closeby Times Square. Value for money, I think this was a most favourable hotel and we have stayed in this city 5 or 6 times previously. P.S. We showed our Australian Automobile Club Membership Card and got 10% off the daily rate. I booked the hotel over the web at hotels-and-discounts.com

I stayed at this midtown location, on west 36th streeet, on june 9th. The location was pretty good, about a 5-10 minute walk to the subway. The cab ride home from the theater was $5 or$6. Our room was very small, with a single and a double bed, small armoire, desk and a standard comfort inn bathroom. It was all really clean, and the breakfast was better than expected. They served a few kinds of juice, coffee, cereals, toast, bagels, and fruit(apples, bananas, oranges).The staff was hard working and generally pleasant. I paid $179, for a thursday night, which seemed like a decent value, considering new york hotel prices!

I turned to Trip Advisor for a weekend stay in November 2005 at the Comfort Inn. For what it's worth, here's my experience. The lobby is nicely lit, lots of shiny brass, and it's clean. The elevator up to the sixth floor was tight, the smallest I've ever ridden. It was a taste of things to come. The bed's headboard was two feet to the right of the doorway. A desk lay six feet straight ahead, then the wall. Walking in anywhere in the room meant circling the bed. But the place was clean, including the small bathroom with shower (no tub). There was ample closet space. I'd guess the room was 10' by 10' (3m x 3m).For November, which was bitterly cold, the room was quite warm. Too warm in fact; we left our window open during the day, as there's no thermostat (the whole hotel is heated to same temp. all winter, per agreement with utility company, front desk said.) Not a biig problem. The room was set back from the street and quiet enough. My sister-in-law, her husband and their 1-year-old shared a room next to us. It was about 1/3 bigger for the same price. The hotel's biggest asset is its location. You can't get much closer to Times Square. If you're a budget tourist, this is the place to stay. The continental breakfast was fine -- cereal, milk, coffee and donuts. (My Aussie in-laws thought this was a hoot, as no one in Australia eats donuts for *breakfast.* They'd only heard of such a thing on "The Simpsons.") An attendant lingered in the breakfast room, making sure we had ample milk, coffee etc. He works on tips -- a buck is appreciated.Overall, I'd stay here again if I was on a budget. It's not luxurious. But it's modern and it's clean and it's in Times Square. If you don't plan on spending much time in your room, you'll be fine.

Read all reviews before staying at this hotel. Was still reluctant because the room rate was so reasonable. We stayed for three nights. Would I return? Yes I would. The room was clean, small (it's New York!), location was great, breakfast was more than adequate, and the staff is very friendly. Thank you Comfort Inn for making our stay enjoyable.

We loved this place! It's small and nothing fancy but what do you expect for the price? No view from the windows but within less than 100 steps out the front door you're in the center of Times Square! The air condtioner was loud which was nice bc we heard no one else around. So glad we found this place. We will ablsolutely be back!!!

Just came back from a long week-end in NYC. I agree with everybody. Almost everything was perfect about this hotel (location, cleanliness, friendly staff, small but workable room, decent breakfast, storage room). We got there at lunch time and our room was ready. Perfect! The only, but very important, problem is that I could hardly sleep in our room. The cause: the rooms are not soundproofed at all. We could hear the TV and the children speak in the room next to ours and everything that was going on in the hallway (a family was sharing multiple rooms and was constantly going from one room to the others, screaming, laughing and slamming doors; it was awful…). In addition, it’s New York City; people were coming in and out at all hours, slamming doors and screaming in the small hallway. I had problems falling asleep because of all the noise and was constantly waken up afterwards. In the middle of the night, after 3 or 4, I was finally able to sleep. If you are like me a light sleeper, you better select another hotel. Since we are more experienced with the subway system now, next time we plan to stay away from Times Square. For about the same price, we will get a much better hotel. We may even be ready to pay a bit more to get a good night sleep.

Just returned from staying at the Comfort Inn Midtown for 5 nights. Total price per night including taxes was $200. We usually stay at 3 or 4 star hotels but tried out a 2-star for a change (and price was much better). The hotel was small (in size and number of rooms) which was nice for a change. The elevator was big enough for about 8 people (or 3 with luggage). Warning - watch out for the elevator door! It slams FAST and HARD and I still have the bruise on my hand to prove it. The halls were very narrow. Our room was the smallest I have ever stayed in but was adequate. I called it a "one-way room" because only one person could walk around at a time! The window air conditioner was great and not loud at all - just a quiet hum. We were on the back facing the church next door and heard the church bells a lot which was nice. Actually, that was the only noise we heard the whole trip from our room. The bathroom was larger than I had expected. It even had a large frosted window in it and a large ledge to sit your stuff on. We only had the breakfast 2 mornings and it was fine - bagels, toast, boiled eggs, cereal, donuts, fruit, coffee, orange and apple juice, cappucino, coffee and tea. One person said there were only 4 tables in there, but there were 8 (I think). We did have to wait a couple of minutes one day. I think it would have been nice if the people who were finished would have left and given up their table instead of sitting there planning the day's itinerary while we stood there. The computer room (2 computers, free internet) was a nice plus because we could check on a few things while we were there. All the employees were friendly. One other thing - the doors really do SLAM when you leave your room. They usually started around 7 a.m. All you have to do is keep your hand on the handle and pull it shut and it won't slam. We couldn't figure out why people let them slam so much. Rude, I guess. Anyway, bottom line is this hotel was great for the money and location, I would highly recommend it if you wanted a nice place to sleep and shower, and we would definitely stay there again.

this is a small friendly hotel in a great location and offering excellent value for money, with breakfast included!. We would have no hesitation recommending it to friends and family.One small niggle was the fact that the double glazing did not have an airtight seal and therefore lets through more road noise that it should.

What a gem! We had a very enjoyable stay at this hotel. Given its Times Square location and its relatively inexpensive price, I was a bit apprehensive about what we would get. Our room, however, much surpassed our expectations. Although small, it was nicely furnished and the bathroom was clean and relatively spacious. In fact, the hotel looks as if it was recently refurbished. The entire staff were very accommodating and pleasant to boot! Parking is also a real bargain - just across the street and only $20 per 24 hours, about half of what the other hotels charge. The continental breakfast included bagels, doughnuts, coffee and milk, which is all one really needs. If you're adventurous and want something more for breakfast, try the Cuban restaurant immediately across the street - cheap eats and very good. A real experience. If heading back to midtown, we will stay there in an instant.

As all the other reviewers say this hotel is in a great location, so close to Times Square and of course the subway in Times Square. When we arrived we asked to see the room before we took the luggage up, our room was a good size, from what people had told me about NY hotels I thought we might get a shoe box but this wasn't the case. The room was at the front of the hotel and on the top floor, it was still noisy (street noise) but fine if you can use earplugs. Beds were very comfortable, room and bathroom clean, we always had a good supply of hot water for baths and showers. Breakfast was a plus, you get bagels, doughnuts, cereal, toast, fruit, orange juice, tea and coffee - you basically help yourself grab a table. We got a cab from the hotel to the airport and you pre-pay at reception and it cost $55.00.

My wife and I stayed at the Mid Town Comfort Inn for three nights and enjoyed it tremendously. A luxury hotel it is not, but it was more than adequate and the price was the least expensive that I could find. $170.00 per night with $20.00 per night validated parking fee at a nearby (across the street) parking garage. There is an added savings in the complimentary breakfast. The rooms are small, but adequate. The bed was comfortable and clean. The bath had a combination tub shower. Everything was very clean and was refreshed each day while we were out. The front desk was very cordial and helpful with any questions. I purchased the tickets for the "Red Bus" (Greylines) from the front desk clerk and was told that they could give me a discount. Another savings!
