I requested and received a room away from 46th St. side of the motel and did not experience any excessive outside noise.The Comfort Inn Mid Town's location should over ride the small room reports.

My friend and I stayed three nights at the Comfort Inn Midtown and we were very happy with everything about the hotel. It was my first visit to NYC and I chose this hotel because of reviews on TripAdvisor. I was a little nervous about it because there were a few negative comments in some of the reviews, but our experience was very positive. The staff went out of their way to be helpful to us and our room was very clean and comfortable. We were on the 5th floor and we asked for the front because we wanted the view. It was a bit noisy at times, but we just considered it " the music of the city". It has great, authentic New York City atmosphere, and staying there was an important part of our experience of the city. The location and price make it a terrific deal. I will stay at the Comfort Inn Midtown anytime I can get back to New York.

Nice hotel and a great location, the only down side was the noise in the morning. Our room overlooked the main street and was on the fifth floor. The delivery trucks and binmen start early about 4:15am and woke me up for every morning for the 4 nights we were there. but not my wife! The breakfast is basic but nice.But this is only a small inconvenience for a great location and in my opinion a well run clean hotel. If you do book and want a snack or a drink the bar across the road "O'briens" is ideal, great burgers and very friendly bar staff. Would I go back to the same hotel? Yes.

Stayed on the 12th floor on this hotel in April 2006. We were not expecting much as the cost of the 4 person room was competitive. We were pleasantly surprised!! A comfortable room, excellent location, free coffee (from the reception area), complimentary newspapers and a satisfactory buffet breakfast. Added to these were freindly, competent staff and free luggage storage after checking out.I would not however book private transfers on the return to your airport (as recommended by the hotel) - I would go with a yellow cab, just as easy and cheaper.

Location, location, location. This hotel is less than a block from Times Square and within 4 blocks from Radio City Music Hall and Rockefeller Center. The rooms are basic but very clean. The thing that we liked about the room was that it was very quiet..no streetnoise at all..and we had a beautiful view. The deluxe continential breakfast was very nice and since it is included, it is a great value...We will stay here again.

Location, Location, location! We were a bit concerned about our New York stay as many hotels had had terrible reviews on Trip Advisor. We turned up at the Comfort Inn Midtown and we were really surprised with the hotel. The location is fantasic, bathrooms clean, staff friendly, good breakfast and it was a great stay overall.The location is excellent - a stones throw to Times Square, subway, Macy's, Emipre State etc. Would definitely stay here again.

Booked this hotel via the web for a 1 night stopover on my way back from CT. The location is awesome! Just a block from Times Square, 1/2 block from the Rockefeller Center subway station. The staff was very friendly, both at check in and later when I checked out. A Continental breakfast is offered and was very convenient. The hotel was very clean, even the basement where the ice machine is located. The room itself was very clean, had a coffee pot (which was nice) and.... well that's about all the good I can say about the room. I have never stayed in a room that small. Now don't get me wrong, for a quick one night or just 1 person, it was fine. I couldn't imagine spending a few days in the room with my wife. There just isn't enough room, especially the bathroom. The bathroom was nice and it seems to be recently redone so it is not one of those 30 year old NY bathrooms. The good part is you can do everything by standing in one place :) I could touch all the walls from standing in the middle of the bathroom. Cruise ships have bigger cabins and showers, no kidding.  As others have mentioned, the room was very hot even while it was cool outside. The have signs saying do not open the window so I turned on the window AC and it never got the room cold. The view was of a brick wall 2 feet away :) My friends were staying at the Pennsylvania on 34th street and I went down to meet them. Compared to the Comfort Inn the hotel was very dirty. The hallways were drab and in need of repair as was the room. I would never stay there. I take that back, I might stay there, but not with my wife. I can put up with a lot, including dirty, but she would have problems with it. The the room was twice the size of the room at the Comfort Inn but the room at the Comfort Inn wins hands down! I added this in just for comparison. Oh yea, the line to check in was about 30 minutes. The longest line I saw at the Comfort Inn was 1 person. Would I stay there again, you bet! If I was going by myself or with my wife for just 1 or 2 nights it would be perfect. The location, the cleanliness and the friendly staff make it a nice place to stay.

We chose this hotel after much searching and reading the reviews of many many hotels in Manhattan.We are extremely fussy about cleanliness and can honestly say that the room was clean with a comfortable bed which was also very clean. The air conditioner was quite noisy but was necessary as the room was very warm. We had read that the rooms were small and we expected to be more cramped than we were and although our room was not large it was large enough for what we needed. It contained a double bed, wardrobe, table and chair, bedside table, television stand, iron, ironing board and coffee making facilities. Our room faced a brick wall but we were not in it long enough for this to bother us.The bathroom was a good size and that was also clean, the water pressure on the shower was good and there was a constant supply of hot water. The breakfast was good; being included in the price has to be a bonus in New York.We found all the staff that we came into contact with friendly and helpful.The location we feel could not have been better and the cost of the hotel very reasonable.If we ever return to Manhattan we will definitely choose this hotel again.

This hotel is one-half a block from time square.The staff are great,rooms were clean,the beakfast was good. Rooms on the small side but well maintained. Would return next trip. Canada loves New York City

For the theater district, the location is great. Our room was extremely tiny and uncomfortable, even by New York standards, and there was no means of circulating air. No fan or AC and the windows were right up against another building so they provided no relief (actually, we weren't supposed to open them but we had no choice). The heat was uncontrollable, making it impossible to sleep. They told us there was no other room available. Quite the disappointment after having booked months in advance. Rooms like ours are the type they should have saved till the very end for last minute walk-ins. Check your room first!

While not the swankiest hotel in the midtown area the Comfort Inn Midtown was reasonably priced (for NYC), with reasonably sized rooms (for NYC ) with friendly staff. The rooms and lobby were clean and the breakfast was adequate. However, the room was never at the right temperature and the air conditioner was very loud. Overall it was a positive stay and I would stay there again.

We booked this hotel, after staying at the Muse Hotel the previous year and being impressed by the reviews and the obvious better-value rates. We were very impressed, much better value than the over-rated hotel across the street. Although this is not a boutique hotel, it is perfect for what we are looking for in a new york hotel - excellent location, good value, clean rooms and friendly staff.I was somewhat surprised to read a previous review, stating that the breakfast guy was a 'jobsworth'. The man could not do enough for you in the morning, he also works through the rest of the day in the hotel, so he has is work cut out for him. I wouldn't want to pick up bread if someone is sticking their hands in the container - that's what the tongs are there for!!Overall, probably the best value hotel around Times Square. This was our second visit to NYC and although we loved this hotel, we will probably stay around the Village on our next visit, as Times Square is just far too touristy after a first vist.If you want to stay in Times Square - book this hidden gem.

For our first trip we booked this hotel because of location and price. And we were not sorry!It is a nice little hotel half a block from Times Square. But it is on a guiet street and staying there you would never know the that you were that close to TS. There are several restaurants on the street and a deli, diner, nail salon and tapas bar.Breakfast is included in the price, it's not much, but all you need to get you started in the morning.Our room was of average size, not as cramped as I imagined. Bed was comfortable and the bathroom was nice and clean. I'm very fussy about baths and toilets and was comfortable with what we got. The airconditioner makes a lot of noise, but you get used to it.The staff was ok, some very nice and helpful (doormen, "breakfast guy", housekeeper) the people in reception so and so.I would stay here again and recommend it to everyone.

A great place to stay especially for the fair price, the convinence and close to Time Square, one block away. Continental breakfast a good plus. The room may be small but no problem. Staff courteous and very helpful. Only diassatisfaction was with my poor hearing close caption was not available on the TV. I do though highly recommend this hotel and I travel frequently with my daughter.

We spent four days in New York in March prior to a cruiseand I was SO glad I had chosen the Comfort Inn Midtown.It was extremely cold and windy while we were there and we were glad we could go to wonderful restaurants close by and a short walk to the Broadway shows. Also when we had to leave very early in the morning before the breakfast room opened to attend Regis and Kelly, we found the McDonald's right around the corner very convenient for a quick, hot breakfast before the ordeal of waiting outside the studio in the cold. If you want a beautiful view and various amenities, be prepared to spend about $400 to $500 a night in New York. If you're looking for a spotlessly clean, comfortable hotel in an excellent location, this is it.

I made my reservations at the Comfort Inn after reading the reviews on TripAdvisor. Believe the reviews - we were very pleased with this hotel. It met all of my travel requirements: CLEAN - one of the cleanest rooms I've stayed in, definitely the cleanest I've encountered in NYC.CONVENIENT - you really couldn'd ask for a better location for doing all the tourist-y stuff. It was a great "home base".AFFORDABLE - our rate was $149 a night. Wow.Other notes: the shower pressure was great (hard to find in a hotel sometimes) and we always had hot water. The hotel was generally quiet, although we could hear water pipes at work through the walls at times. The room was a bit small, but I expect that in a large city in an affordable hotel. Our room was on the 2nd floor, so we were able to use the stairs and avoid waiting on the elevator.We definitely plan to stay at the Comfort Inn on our next visit!

Location for Times Square you cannot beat. Hotel room was large enough and cleaned on a daily basis. Limited breakfast with a "jobsworth" attendant very curt and somewhat rude when people didnt use the bread tongues, and place holders in the correct place. To be honest we got some amusement watching his face when this happened.The hotel lift is very small so be aware when taking suitcases upto your room.Dont let these picky remarks put you off as we are going back again for New Year. Location is ideal, rooms clean and large enough. 3 Star hotel in a 5 Star location.

Stayed here for one night and was very impressed with the hotel.The location is great.Very close to Times Square,Radio City,and Rockefeller Plaza.Parking across the street was $20 for 24 hrs.Easy check-in.The rooms were basic but clean.Couldn't beat the price of $150 for midtown Manhattan.Will be staying here again on my next trip to NYC.

After reading the great reviews on this website, me and my boyfriend booked this hotel for a 4 night stay in New York. We stayed at the Milford Plaza 2 years ago and found it OK, but just decided to try somewhere different. However, we were slightly disappointed with this one. Yes it was clean and you really can't fault it for it's excellent location - literally just steps away from practically everything. So in that respect, the value for money was really good. And I'm not one of those people who whinges about ridiculous things like the air con being too loud, but I just found this hotel a bit shoddy. The staff weren't all that helpful and if you wanted something booking then you had to go and ring them yourself which was unusual for a hotel (after visiting hundreds) and little things like that just help you with your trip. The rooms were also unbearably hot and the only way to cool yourself was to use the fan which when we turned it on smelt like a mens urinal (and I'm really not exaggerating) so it made it uncomfortable to sleep (which is all we did in the room).The fabulous breakfast included that everyone talks about is just average - if that. You eat off of paper plates and with plastic knives and forks, which again I know may sound snobby but it just felt shabby. The man in the tiny breakfast room, which we had to wait outside for space at least 2 mornings (it only seated 4 tables) was good and kept the area clean though.All in all we had a good stay but it's nice to feel a bit special when visitng somewhere as great as New York, and this hotel just didn't do that. We travelled on a budget and never stay in posh hotels - as long as they're clean and in a good location I'm pleased enough. However, the strange bellman at this hotel didn't even help with our bags and when you pass all those lovely hotels and see what goes on in them it just makes you see how the Comfort Inn is a bit run down and needs better mannered staff.

This hotel has to be rated excellent for the following reasons;. So cheap especially if you book online, myself n my sis stayed for 5 days for £313 between us.The location is unbelievble, in the centre of times square.almost everything is in walking distance (we got the sub twice, to the statue of liberty, and central park). No need to pay for taxis.its right next to the times square info centre so buy ur tickets there for the statue of liberty n u save queing time.The staff are so friendly and helpful, they let our friend (from brooklyn) stay for free and brought us blankets, without us even asking can she stay. the free continental breakfast is beautiful with, toast, bagels, cereal, dognuts, juice, tea n coffee, and the guy who serves it keeps offering you more.the rooms are very clean but basic, it has cable tv to in ur room, the maid is lovely very trustworthyI want to go back next year and will deffo be staying here again. If you want a cheap stay in new york definatley stay here you'll save a fortune.

Our room was located on the seventh floor facing a building. The gentleman that checked us in told us that he was going to put us on the quiet side of the hotel. Quiet meant facing a brick wall, which really didn't bother my husband and I. The main problem was the temperature of the room. It was uncomfortably warm and there was no way to turn the heat down. We voiced our concerns at the desk and the said that they would look intoit. Obviously there was ot much that anyone could do, since the heating system seems to be automatic. Even though there was a sign that said not to open the window, we did anyway. Unfortunately this did not help the temperature of the room. I'm not sure what the answer to the problem was. The morning breakfast was quite adequate and the location could not be beat. Maybe if it is cold outside itwould not be a problem. I should have tried plugging in the air conditioning unit to see if that would have cooled off the room.

Ok.. now i've stayed in hotels all over the world (from $$$ to $) and I must say for the price you pay, this is the best hotel I've ever stayed at. Stayed there my 1st & 2nd times in NYC (both being a single female traveler). Hotel is a 1/2 block from Times Square & Theatre District and 2 blocks from Rockerfella Center, NBC Studios, 5th Avenue Shopping. ALL hotel staff was more than helpful and extremely friendly. Hotel was very clean, and was not a bad size for a NY hotel room. Featured on a quiet side street with no traffic noise at night. Very secure & safe… would recommend it to any one! Hotel windows didn't have the best view, because you are on a side street, but who wants to stay in the hotel all day? Especially when you're so close to the action!

Just returned from a trip to New York. Spent a week at the Comfort Inn, Midtown. I chose this hotel after much research on the Trip Advisor web site and can honestly say that I thought this hotel was excellent. The location of the hotel was great, just 2 mins walk and you are in Times Square. I went with my two daughters and we stayed in a room for 4 which had 2 queen sized beds in. The room was not big but was adequate. It was very clean and sheets and towels were changed every day. Our room was at the back of the hotel so we didn't have a "view" but this was not important as we didn't spend much time in the hotel room! The staff in the hotel were always very helpful and friendly. Breakfast was included in the price and this included toast, cereal, bagels, doughnuts, fresh fruit, tea, coffee and fruit juice. If I ever return to New York I would definitely stay at this hotel again and would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a reasonably priced hotel in an excellent location.

This hotel is perfectly situated and is the bargain of the century. For about $100 you stay on 46th St close to Times Square, free contintental breakfast and a clean room with pleasant staff. What more could you ask for? If you're looking for luxury this is not the place. If you want comfortable accomodations at a reasonable price it is the place for you.

This was my second time staying two nights at this hotel in the past eight months. I got a great midweek rate with my Auto Club discount, $98.99. I arrived about 2 1/2 hours prior to check-in but was given a room anyway. Check-in was lengthy because I arrived on March 1st, the day a new computer system was introduced, so there were some glitches with it, but that was to be expected and I didn't mind, since I was early anyway. The room I had this time, while still a queen-size, was a bit larger than the last time I stayed there, as was the bathroom. However, it seemed a bit more worn down than before: the bedspread had seen better days, the carpet was shredded where it met the bathroom, the telephone cord was frayed, the phone books were outdated, and there was a strange dent in the wall. I was on the sixth floor on the church side (the hotel is adjacent to a Catholic Church) so I did hear the church bells regularly. The room was very hot. When I asked the cleaning lady how to adjust the heat she simply opened the window, in the middle of a snowstorm! And there's still the problem with the doors that close themselves and slam loudly while doing so. If you're a business traveler and needing to get up in the morning this might not bother you, but I was there on pleasure and didn't enjoy the slams at 6:30 in the morning. Overall, however, this is still a good deal and the location can't be beat. You're right between subway stops at Times Square and Rockefeller Center, and my favorite Cuban restaurant, Havana Central, is just down the street. (Check out their dulce de leche martinis.) In fact, just about anything you could possibly need is within walking distance, the staff is pleasant and helpful, and the free continental breakfast will save you a few bucks.

Trying to find a hotel in NY was harder than I expected, I didn't realize that just staying for one night was expensive almost everywhere I looked until I found the Comfort Inn Midtown. If you use your triple A card you recieve a discount of $99 a night (we stayed on a Sunday night). Yes the room was small, but for two people it was all we needed. Very clean, staff was very nice and there was free continental breakfast which was good. There is a deli only a few buildings down for a great lunch or snack. I would definetely reccomend this hotel.

This hotel exceeded my expectations. I arrived 3 hours before check-in but was given a room right away. Everybody at this hotel was helpful and pleasant. The room was small, but it was spotless, quiet, and featured all the amenities. And, as everbody says, the location can't be beat. I will definitely stay here again. It is a budget hotel in price only - a real New York City jewel.

Similar to the last post, problems may occur if you check-in late at night.We were 2 couples, & we booked this hotel after spending hours looking at other reviews & prices etc. We booked the room over the telephone directly with Applecore Hotels in September 2005 & I received a fax confirming our booking. It did state on the fax that if we were going to check-in after 10 pm to let the hotel know in advance. As our flight wasn't due to land until around 11 pm, I sent the hotel an e-mail a month ago to let them know. I never received an acknowledgement even though I requested one. The week before we went, I sent another e-mail, this time directly to Applecore Hotels, also requesting that they acknowledge this, but again, no response.When we finally arrived at the hotel, it was 1am & as soon as we stepped into the lobby, the clerk looked up, knew our names but then proceeded to say that a slight problem had occurred & that due to a 'medical emergency', the last guests who were in our room had to stay on for another night & that he had made arrangements for us to stay at a hotel down the road for the same price for 1 night only. The other hotel was Super 8, again owned by Applecore. We didn't have a lot of choice at that time in the morning, especially as we knew that they already had our credit card details. We were bundled into a taxi & given $5 to pay the fare, and we literally drove about 200 yards up the road to the other hotel.We didn't want to bother unpacking for 1 night & thought about staying there for the rest of our trip, a further 3 nights, but it was around $50 more expensive per night. It was a good job we didn't! Our room was overlooking the street, & the noise was unbearable all night long. The curtains didn't close & the blinds were all tattered & ripped, the lighting in both the bedroom & the bathroom was dismal.The next morning we checked out, & walked back to the Comfort Inn. I was pleasantly surprised at our rooms. They were so peaceful! No noise at all (no view either) but at least we could sleep OK. The bed was kingsize & very comfortable. There was loads of space for clothes, iron, hairdryer, coffee making & a large TV.The bedroom/bathroom was so much better than the other hotel, also very clean.There was also FREE internet access in the lobbyThe breakfast was the usual, cereal, toast, bagels & choice of pastries & fruit. They even had Tetley T-Bags! Couldn't complain about the facilities there.The main thing about this hotel is the location. You simply walk out of the lobby, turn right & within 1 minute, you are standing outside TGI Fridays, right in Times Square. By the way, look out for the web cam directly outside of TGI's-It's great fun having a morning wave into the camera & lots of people obviously had family/friends at home on the internet looking at www.earthcam.com where it's real time.On the way back to the hotel every night, we stopped at a Cuban bar a few doors up from the hotel for a nightcap. Brilliant atmosphere, great music & lovely Cubre Libres!All in all, yes, it was great shame about the beginning of this trip, but once settled in, we were all happy to have chosen this hotel & it would be my first choice when we return to New York.(We paid $109 Fri night $139 Sat & Sun, this rate was per room & included breakfast, but not taxes)Please feel free to ask any questions.

Hotel is a great deal- especially when you book far in advance. Unfortunately, don't expect your room to be there if you are coming in late at night. We arrived at 11:30pm and were told that they had given our 2 rooms away because they couldn't charge our card. 2 hours later and on the phone with credit card company who was telling us that we had been charged for the rooms that night, we had the night desk person offer us 2 rooms at 3 times the rate we booked. We had to walk around times square and find a small hotel for the night and had to come back the next day to deal with the manager. Not a good way to start your trip! Once the manager cleared everything up and apologized (we were still out an extra $300), things seemed to be looking up. On our 2nd night there, my friend caught one of the desk people going into our room to look for "tape"- we had not been told or called and so he went in and watched them while they moved a couple of things around and left.As much as it was a great deal initially, sometimes it's true that you get what you pay for.

Was a little nervous about this hotel, but had read the reviews and reckoned it was worth a chance. The location is great - Times Square at the end of the road. The staff were friendly and helpful and the free breakfast was a bonus. The room was a little cramped - but who cares? It was nice and warm and very clean. The bed was the most comfortable I have ever had in a hotel, and even the pillows were great. I am recommending this to everyone I know - it is a real bargain.

Great hotel in the middle of midtown. Great value and ok sized rooms. Continental breakfast in the best ive had in a budget inn! Look for Antonio doing breakfast, he will look after you. All in all a great place to stay in NYC. Would stay there again.

This small hotel just off Time Square is just what it is advertised plus you get a staff that genuinely makes you feel you are welcome. From instructions how to ride the subway to getting half price tickets for some shows, Ivonne and CDB were a wealth of information and also eager for out-of-towners, new to the city to enjoy themselves. Rooms are small but newly remodeled, clean, and very realistically priced. We will stay there again.S. Schenck - New Orleans

This is a remarkable value in the heart of the theatre district. You`re literally a one minute walk to Times Square and not much further to Rockerfeller Center and Fifth Avenue shopping. Everything in this 79 room hotel is compact, including the welcoming mahogany and marble lobby. The staff greets you warmly and they are eager to respond to your questions and requests. There is a single elevator that will take you to your compact, but well thought out room. Everything seems new here. You`ll find very nice neo-shaker furnishings, floral patterned, valanced draperies and matching bedspreads. Our mattress was firm and extremely comfortable. The carpeting and colorfully bordered wallpaper are unblemished. There is also subtle recessed ceiling lighting and a small but adequate corner closet. We were on the top floor in room 904 with a queen sized bed. We were on the side of the building and didn`t hear a sound from the street or from neighboring guests. Rooms ending in 01 and 02 are directly on the 46th street side and will probably have street noise. The compact, sparkling bathroom is all new with floor to ceiling white tiles, marble floor, pedestal sink and gleaming fixtures....also Comfort Inns` signature curved shower bar. You`ll also find all of Comfort Inns` regular amenities here, including free local calls, iron/ironing board, newspaper, and available toiletries from housekeeping, just in case you`ve forgotten something. There is also a very good free expanded continental breakfast in the compact, but pleasant breakfast room off the lobby. This includes, pastries, bagels, breads, juices, yogurts, fruit, cereal, coffee and even cappucino. For all this we paid an unbelievable $89 per night. Housekeeping keeps everything spotless here and maintenance is also impressive. I challenge anyone to find a better rate for this kind of quality in New York. We met friends who were staying at a neighboring hotel and paying nearly 3 times as much for a shabby, dirty room, a rude staff, and no breakfast. We`ll definitely be making this our hotel home whenever we visit the city. Not to be missed!!

After reading several favourable reviews of this property, we stayed there for the 2nd time in the last 8 months. Once again, the rooms were clean and of ample size (especially for NYC). The location near Times Square is ideal to walk to many locations or to access the nearby subway lines. Staff are great to deal with and very helpful.We will definitely be returning to this hotel in the future.

We stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown for two nights, and our stay couldn't have been better!For us the LOCATION of this hotel, along with the fair price, sold us.The staff was also very helpful and pleasant. We arrived 3 hours before check-in, and they did allow us to check in early.We were on the 9th floor... room 903. It was small, but not as small as I thought it would be! The room was spotless, and the bathroom was fine. While there is no counter, there is a large windowsill that you can put your toiletries on. Our view looked out to another building, but we could also see some NY sights!This hotel is IN the theatre district, and is in walking distance to MANY attractions. You can get to the airport via a $28 cab ride, or take the train and bus, which only costs $4 per person.Overall, I don't think we'd stay anywhere else in NYC!

This hotel exceeded my expectations. The location was perfect and the staff from the front desk to the bellhop was friendly and nice. I felt welcome and the staff often went out of their way to accomodate. I was offered coffee so many times when walking thru the lobby. Great experience. An excellent place to spend my MLK weekend.

When my son and I had an opportunity to stay an extra night in NY but hadn't made a hotel reservation, I read in the NY Times Guide to NY that the Comfort Inn Midtown was a reasonable choice for budget travelers like us. I called at the last minute and got a double room for $100, and I couldn't believe the value! The room was small, but clean and modern. No view to speak of, but very quiet on the back side of the hotel. Everything worked, beds were comfortable, and a fairly good continental breakfast was available beginning at 7 a.m. The location was extremely convenient, near theaters, subway, Midtown attractions. I am recommending this place to everyone I know and plan to stay there the next time we are visiting New York.

We have just returned from 7 nights at this hotel. It has been wonderful. The location couldn't be better. A few minutes walk from nearest metro station and Times Square. 10 to 15 minutes walk from bus station where we were dropped by shuttle bus from Newark Airport. Very pleasant check in with no question about not being able to have our room before check in time.2nd floor back room plenty big enough for city hotel. Deliciously comfy bed. Everything working in the bathroom and all spotlessly clean. View of concrete wall and quite dark but this was compensated by being completely quiet. No sound of traffic at any time. We thought this was a great bonus considering it is right in the centre. Why do people slam doors though? There's no need. With care they could be closed with a little click. This was the only noise we heard. Don't know how anybody can complain about the free breakfast. Juice, cereal, coffee, chocolate, bagels, bread, jam, philly etc, all looked after by a fastidious guy who kept it all spotlessly clean.Don't like to criticise this hotel at all but there was just one thing. Our room was never made up until about 3pm. This meant that it was a bit of a problem if we fancied going back to have a little rest in the afternoon - we usually went out about 7.15am. Only a small thing but that would have made it a perfect budget city hotel. As it is it is pretty damned near!!!! Would return again any time.

The best thing about this hotel is the location - walk down the street and you are in the middle of Times Square - you can't fault that! The room was an ok size - a long time since it has been renovated though - we had to change rooms from a room at the front of the building - garbage trucks all night! But our room towards the back of the hotel was much better - the hotel has a very ancient lift - still works but feels very rickety - free breakfast included - basically donuts, toast, coffee and tea and juice - not much else - If you could pay the same rate and be in as good a location then I would look for somewhere else a bit more modern - but if it is all you can afford, and want to be in the middle of the manhattan action and do not have high expectations then this is the place for you - nothing wrong with it - just is very basic.

My girldfriend and I (both in our early 20's) stayed at the Comfort Inn for 2 nights (January 1st and 2nd).We arrived at 1h30 PM on January the 1st and were told that no room were ready since everyone went to bed late the night before bla bla bla (room maid began their shift at 9h30 AM so...) by the rude receptionnist who told us that check-in was at 3h PM and not before. Coming from the Barclay Intercontinental where we had a room at 8H30AM, we felt kinda mad, but still, waited.We got our room at 2h45 PM. The room was on the 5th floor which was obviously on the small side. The AC unit wasn't working and the heating system was way to hot, so we had to sleep with the window open all night (but it wasn't that bad, not that noisy outside...well, that's before 7h AM when the nearby church rings it's bells.)The bathroom was discusting, hair (and pubic hair) rolling all over the floor. The location and the price however cannot be beat! The good thing about having a crappy room is that you definitly don't want to stay inside. Therefore, you spend more time in NY than in your room!

This hotel has a terrific location--midway between Rockefeller Center and Broadway. Room was generous in size with a queen bed but no opportunity for a rollaway for an additional person, despite being assured that this was possible through Hotels.com. Price was very reasonable for date (Christmas week) and location. Climate control was not so great--room seemed warm and hard to turn the heat down and 1 towel looked to have hair on it (though appeared not to have been used). Positives include location, location, location, free use of computer with printer in lobby, small exercise facility and free generous breakfast including good bagels, donuts, cold cereal, coffee, juice, fresh apples and bananas and firm mattress. All in all a good value for the price and a discount of 10% if over age 50.

Just returned from a pleasant weekend trip to New York where we stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown. Can’t say enough good things about a clean and attractive, reasonably priced hotel, conveniently located in the Times Square-Theater District. Our 6th floor room was recently renovated along with new furnishings.Although on the smaller side, the room was more than comfortable and accommodated a Queen size bed. The location couldn’t be better with major attractions, such as Times Square, Empire State Building, St. Patrick’s Cathedral, Macy’s , Rockefeller Center, Radio City and Central Park, within easy walking distance. The hotel staff were all extremely pleasant and in the mornings, guests were provided a complimentary breakfast of pastries, bagels, fruit, coffee and juices. Definitely planning to stay here again on return visits to New York City!

My husband, sons (ages 3 and 6) and I had stayed at The Hampton Inn for one night the first week of December. We wanted to extend our trip, but The Hampton was booked, so we chose the Comfort Inn Midtown for our second night. We chose this hotel because the price could not be beat, and the reviews on this website were favorable. We paid under $300 (total with tax)for one night ,while all the other rooms we had looked up online were $400 plus. The hotel is clean and the staff is very friendly, but the rooms are very small. The window in our room had a wall air conditioner in it, and the blinds above the AC were closed. When I peeked out the window, all I pretty much saw was another building or wall, very close. The room was a little dark because of this lack of outside light. The heating system is old; we had a radiator in our room, which had to be manually turned on.I was concerned that the room would get too hot, but it didn't.( There was cold air coming in the room from the window air condioner.) The radiator was enclosed behind a door (with a panel on it that allowed for the heat to escape.)Behind this door, in front of the radiator, was the largest rat trap I have ever seen.(I think it was maybe the only rat trap I have ever seen!) I suppose this is common in New York, but I would have preferred not to have seen it. Also, two of the pillows in our room were torn; you could see the stuffing inside of them. Maybe our expectations were a little high because we had just come from a hotel that had been recently upgraded, and had larger rooms. We're thankful that the price was right, and that everyone was friendly.(The bellhop was especially helpful, and kind to my kids.)However, we don't think this hotel will be our first choice when we return to New York.

We stayed here for 5 nights, from November 30 through December 5. I booked it because of all the good reviews on Tripadvisor, AND because it was probably the least expensive hotel in the area. What a gem it turned out to be. It is one half block from Times Square, yet our room was very quiet. Though small, the room was very clean and comfortable. We were on the 7th floor with a view of the roof of the church next door. (By the way, one of the other recent reviews here said that you can have a view of the Empire State Building: not true, they must have confused this Comfort Inn with a different one). One peculiarity was that it seemed that the radiator-type heat was always on, which is good because it was very cold in NYC, but the only way to reduce the heat to a comfortable level was to turn on the air conditioner. It worked, so no problem. The people at the front desk were extremely helpful and attentive. They found deals for us to various attractions, and booked a sedan for us back to the airport, as well as let us store our luggage until we left in the afternoon. When we return to New York City we will most definitely stay there again.

After searching for a "reasonably-priced" place to stay in Midtown Manhattan, this is what we settled on. (There really is no such thing as a clean, nice place to stay that is truly reasonable in NYC.) At any rate, we were very pleasantly surprised. If you close the curtains (thereby eliminating the view of the brick wall) you might imagine yourself in a quaint country inn. The room was a bit small, but it was cozy, clean and really quite lovely. We didn't spend much time in the room, but that was not the point of this vacation.We would stay there again in a New York minute. :-)

We stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown for five nights in November. It may not be the ritz but it is a very comfortable, clean hotel in a fantastic location (times square is one block away). The staff are very friendly and helpful - I wanted to change rooms after the first night as it was unseasonably warm in New York and the room was unbearably hot - we were given a new room no problem. All this with a free breakfast! I searched for weeks to find the perfect hotel but having read the reviews on tripadvisor I opted for a reasonably priced comfortable hotel and found a gem!

My husband and i stayed at the comfort inn midtown from 2 sep-9sep.We got a great rate at 149 dollars pr night and the location was just the best,espesially for us travelling to New York for the first time.The housekeeper kept it clean and we got fresh towels every day.And what a quiet hotel...i can´t belive that i stayed a half block from times square.Minus for small room and our window facing a brick wall.Remember to tip the man in the breakfast room,he was so helpful and nice. He is also the man who`s vacuing the hallways,so he is working for his bucks :o).It`s in a such a great location that we didn`t take a taxi once...used the subway for long distances but walked almost everywhere.We had a great time and would defenetly stay there again.

Stayed here last December, and it was a fantastic hotel to saty in. We were there for 4 nights. The room was non-smoking as requested, and imagine our joy when we got to the room (near the top of the hotel), flung back the curtains to see a fantatstic view of the empire state building, as it is just the block behind. When you book, try and book a room at the 'back left corner' of the hotel, to get the view. Waking up to the empire state building in the dawn and seeing it lit up at night was brilliant. Clean hotel, decor a little shabby in the room but hey. Clean towels daily. The concierge was lovely, very helpful, couldn't do enough for us. Great location as well, right by macys and fifth ave, subway on the corner of the block. We flew into Newark airport and took the airtrain to Penn station, this hotel is a couple of blocks walk away - no need for a cab.We're off to NYC in a couple of weeks, unfortunlaty left it too late to book in here again :( trying the new yorker instead this time, will see how it measures up!

Hey, for under $200 bucks (since my husband is considered a "mature traveler" at age 51--we got a 10% discount)--this place isn't half bad.Here's what was good: The price, the adequate free breakast, and close to theaters & shopping--we walked everywhere!! For under $200--the rooms were mildly spacious. We were four blocks from Jersey Boys (great show!! I highly recommend it), and the hotel arranged for a shuttle to take us back to the airport (23 bucks each)...The not so good: Two not so plush towels (asked for more, but never got them); no view; rather noisy all over, and not so good toiletries or lighting in the bathroom.I'd stay there again--not fancy, but bearable!

Great location and clean with wireless internet, coffeemaker, tv, iron and a one computer-printer business center. Linens seemed fresh and of decent quality. The room was tiny and had no view but was still a bargain. As to a former comment about loud door noise, my door wouldn't lock unless you slammed it. I mean that's what the staff told me to do to get my door to lock -- and didn't understand when I tried to explain that it would disturb the neighbors. They could work on that issue for sure....

My husband and I stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown earlier this month. We arrived in NYC very early in the AM and they stored our luggage until our room was ready - shortly after 10:30 AM - hours before official check-in time! Throughout our 3 night stay we found staff to be very helpful and pleasant.This Comfort Inn is in a great location for attending the theater and not bad for exploring the city. And the price is certainly resonable for Manhattan. The room was clean, the bathroom was small but attractive, the shower had good water pressure and plenty of hot water. The room was very small, however, and the mattress on our bed had seen better days - saggy in the middle. The bedspread was clean but very tired. The biggest problem was the noise from the hallway. Any time someone closed a door on the hall it reverberated in our room loudly enough to startle you out of a deep sleep. We turned on the AC fan to try and drown out the noise but it was not enough. The view from our window was of a brick wall about a foot away. This made the room dark and the lighting was not adequate enough to compensate for this. I would stay here again IF there was a room where the closing doors on the hall did not make me jump and the mattress was not sagging.

My husband and I stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown from 23 - 25 September and couldn't have been happier. Before arrival I contacted the hotel to request a particular room and they couldn't have been more helpful. Our room was spacious, clean and looked like it had been recently refurbished. Yes, it was a little noisy at night but what do you expect when you are just a stones throw from Times Square! At least if you stay up late in Times Square you only have a couple of minutes walk back to your hotel!We are already planning a return trip to New York (which in my opinion is the best city in the world!) and will not hesitate in rebooking the hotel.

I was in town for a two day seminar and the host hotel (Westin) was full, so I went searching for a place to stay. Settled on the Comfort Inn for it's location and value. (About half the price of the host hotel, even with the group rate) I obviously was going to give up a few luxuries, but what the heck, I saved the company a few bucks. Review: Negatives-Very small room (Maybe 12 feet by 12 feet) The plumbing from my neighbor was quite loud and woke me up both mornings at about 6 am. Positives-Great value. Outstanding location, just a block from the heart of Times Sqare. Computer office in the lobby for those who do not have a laptop. Continental breakfast. Friendly staff. For the sheer value and location, this is an excellent hotel. Just don't plan to throw a party in your room.

The Comfort is in an outstanding location if you like action and convenience. The hotel itself is about what you would expect in a budget accommodation. The hotel is located a block and a half from the Rockefeller Center subway station and is easily accessed. We were in 2 different rooms. We had a street facing room for the first night..a little more noisy since the trash pickups show up at 5 am in the front. We requested a room in the back and the staff was able to oblige. Unlike other reviews, we had no problem with the staff. Both rooms, particularly the first, needed to be remodeled....carpet worn and dirty looking....but the rest of the decor was fine and the bathrooms clean. The bottom line is that prices are outrageous in NYC and this is one of the better in the budget category

Due to a family situation I had to cancel my reservation. The manager, Rajni Rikh, refused to give me a cancellation number. Even after I expressed concerns about having proof of cancellation, she became very irritated. I called the main Comfort Inn number and they too refused to provide a cancellation number. If you have to cancel at this hotel monitor your credit card carefully since you won't have proof you cancelled.

The reason I give this hotel 5 circles is because of value. I only spent one night at the Comfort Inn Midtown for business. I was able to get a AAA rate that was very good for midtown Manhattan. The room was clean and the bed relatively comfortable. Location, location, location ... if you want a midtown address without the high rates, this is the choice. Service was good too.

My husband and I and our two sons stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown from August 22-25. I used this website and relied upon others' reviews when making the booking, as we had never been to NYC before. Everyone was basically right on in their reviews. I thought that since I had used this website to make my decision, I would contribute to it as well to help others. The hotel is not new, nor is it "The Ritz", but it is very clean and the location is perfect. Times Square is such an exciting place to be, and we were steps away from it. We basically walked everywhere, as the hotel is centrally located. The room was small, but we were gone right after breakfast and didn't return until late in the evening, so it wasn't a big deal. The lighting in the room could have been better, the fan in the bathroom wasn't working, we couldn't open a window, and the air conditioner could have been quieter, but these weren't major things. The continental breakfast was okay - nothing spectacular - but it started us off in the morning and allowed us to get on with our day without first having to find a place to eat. There are some good restaurants in the area - we recommended Bubba Gump Shrimp (named for the movie Forrest Gump).Staying at the Comfort Inn Midtown allowed us to make NYC an affordable holiday. It is perfect if you are looking for something clean, well located and affordable at the same time. We loved NYC and had a terrific time. Hope you will, too.

We spent 2 nights at the Comfort Inn Midtown 8/18/05-8/20/05. It was great. We got there on the 18th at 11:30am, asking to check our bags. Instead they handed us our room cards and said we could enjoy our room right then. The room was nice. We were on the 6th floor overlooking W 46th Street, and with the A/C on, we rarely heard the street noise. The woman who cleaned the room was very sweet, always wishing us a good morning and a safe trip when we left. The front desk staff was nothing special. They certainly didn't go out of their way to give us advice and were always on their cell phones. But whatever... We took a picture from the steps of the hotel. The red Bank of America sign down the street is in Times Square. If you stay here, do yourself a favor and walk over to Tony's DiNapoli at 147 West 43rd Street. The food was so good, we ate there twice. I highly recommend the caesar salad. And a friendly warning, the pitcher of sangria is huge!

This hotel is in a great location. It is less than a block from Times Square and nearby everything a tourist would want to do.We got there early in the morning, and although we were not able to check in, we were able to drop our luggage off and they stored it in a locked room. The room was relatively small, but I was only there to sleep and shower. It was very clean and had an iron, ironing board, and extra pillows in the small closet. There was a window air conditioner in the room, which was relatively quite, and quickly cooled the room down, which was a relief being it was nearly 100 degrees and very humid in New York! The bathroom was a decent size and stocked w/ amenities. It also had a small coffee maker. My only complaint about the bathroom was the lack of water pressure in the shower.The staff was very freindly and helpful. We had gone to NYC to go to a Yankees game. We knew that we could easily take the subway into the Bronx, but not sure which one to go on. The lady at the front desk was very helpful in advising us what train to get on and told us exactly where the subway station was (about a block away). When we checked out, we had several hours before we had to be at the airport and again they held our luggage for us as we explored more of the city.The bellhop, was a very nice gentleman who offered to get us a car service to the airport for a flat rate. We took him up on this, as it was about the same price as the cab fare getting there was and we did not have to worry about hailing our own cab. I didn't have the free breakfast they offered, but it looked like there was plenty of food, bagels, danish, coffee etc. There are numerous restaurants right on the same block as the hotel, there is a very reasonably priced deli nearby, that had a phenomenal breakfast. I would definelty stay in this hotel again. It is in a great location. And the price can not be beat. For a 2 night stay, in a room with 2 twin beds for a weekend it only cost $360. I have been to NYC a few times before and have stayed at more expensive places, and I can tell you from experience the more expensive places, although they are bigger and have a more elegant lobby, this place can definetly compete with them. So, if you are going to NYC to have fun and explore the city and just need a clean and comfortable place to sleep and shower, this is the place.

We did try to make a reservation directly to the hotel, but the man was very unfriendly and said the hotel was full for this period. When we did call choicehotels we made the reservation with no trouble.The location is good for broadway and theatervisits. The breakfast is simple but oke, only the breakfastroom has only about 5 little tables and the hotel has many rooms and there is a sign not to take breakfast items to your room - sometimes you just have to wait to sit down for breakfast.The view from the room was realy something else, I donot want to think what will happen if there is a fire - It will be impossible to get out through this window!!Also see the picture taken in the bathtub, yak -it is realy dirty -We only used the shower.

My husband and I stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown in mid-June. It was our first time in NYC and we wanted to be centrally located without having to pay through the nose for a room we'd hardly be in.We got there early in the morning and were able to check in right away. The staff were all friendly - the porter was especially nice. Our room was larger than I expected (based on comments on this site). It was very bright and clean. We had a street view, but at night we didn't hear any noise since we had the A/C on - it was so hot when we were there.Breakfast was basic but hit the spot - bagels, cereal, fuit, yougurt, juice. We didn't use the gym since we were walking 12 hours a day, but it had a stationary bike, treadmill, etc. There is a computer if you need to check your home e-mail or your fave website.And the biggest bonus - it's 100% smoke-free. Beautiful!!The only thing that could concern some people would be the elevator. There is only one and sometimes, it could be busy. We were on the 8th floor, so a few times we took the stairs. Not a problem for us, but some may find it annoying. There is a little screen by the button, so you can see where the elevator is and which way it is going.Would we stay there again? Yes, if the price isn't more than what we paid, which was $169/night. We were pleased with our choice.

I wanted to take the time to write on here about this hotel considering I read alot of reviews and based my stay upon them - so I thought I better add my two cents in as well! I stayed here for a week - we were greeted by a very UNFRIENDLY woman at the front desk, our toliet overflowed the second last day and flooded the bathroom, and while we were out they fixed it, but left a huge hair ball in the tub and a pile of 20 or so wet towels in the bathroom (I called front desk and they delt with this asap). The man who I assume in the bellhop - was friendly and super nice and offered much help. We never stayed for breakfast, but it looked like there were alot of food. More importantly, I would stay in this hotel again without hesitation because of the amazing location!!!!!!!!! It is so worth the tiny cramped rooms - your not there for the room and view anyways - atleast I wasnt - you are 1 min walk from times square and a 3 min walk from 5th ave. What more could a girl ask for!?!? Stay here if the price doesnt jump over $250.00 US - If it does you might be able to find a nicer looking hotel for the same price - but JUMP on it if its any cheaper - WELL WORTH IT! =)

The Comfort Inn Midtown was perfect for us. We walked from Grand Central Station with two kids and carryon-type luggage in just about five minutes. It is located in Little Brazil right beside Broadway at Times Square. We couldn't have asked for a better location that was central to everything! There are restaurants of all sizes, ethnic tastes, and price ranges within sight. The staff was friendly and helpful. If you are going on the Gray Line bus tour, buy your tickets at the hotel for a discount. We are already planning a return trip and will definitely book our room at this hotel. I've stayed in four different hotels in the area. This is definitely the cleanest, safest, best staffed, and most convenient.Pam from WV

We have remained to this comfortable Hotel for about 10 days in the first days of the new year. We had asked at reservation's time, to reserve one room up the sixth floor, couse we had read here that so was better. So, we had one excellent room with sunlight and sight of the skyline too! The room was large and cleaned up everyday, the airy bathroom with a comfortable tube and always changed cloths. The breakfast was really good and various, and the desk's people very kind! The location is ideal in order to move easy in Manhattan, just a block from Times Square, with all the metropolitan's line. If you want a truly comfortable place to a reasonable price, this is the perfect hotel! I definitively recommend it to everybody!

For the money this is the businessThe location 1/2 block from Times Square is where you want to beWhilst the rooms are small everytning else is excellent even down to the breakfastThe 3 Open Top Bus Tours from Times Sq for $49 over 2 days is a great way to see the city

Long review, but worth reading before you make your reservation...Back in April (2 1/2 months before our arrival date), we reserved two double rooms at the Comfort Inn Midtown for 3 adults and 3 children (reserved on ChoiceHotels). When we arrived at the hotel in July, we were told that there were no double rooms available because the hotel was undergoing renovations. (We didn't see any signs of renovations during our stay.)The front desk clerk offered to put us into two rooms, each with one Queen bed and a cot. We said this would be OK, but only if we were charged the rate that was advertised the previous evening on ChoiceHotels for this room type and date ($55 less per room than the rate we were quoted for our double rooms). He said he could only offer us a 10% discount ($14 less per room). He offered to walk us down the street to another hotel if we didn't want these rooms. We said this was unacceptable since we had to get ready to go see a show in a couple of hours. We then called Choice Hotels Customer Service (CHCS) using the front desk phone.I told the CHCS clerk about what had happened. He asked me if the hotel had offered to pay for our rooms at the other hotel. I told him that they hadn't. He then put my call on hold and contacted the hotel to get more information. The office manager told him that they had one double room available and that they had told us this. When the CHCS clerk came back to my call, he told me this and I informed him that this was not true. I told him I was fine with having only one double room, but only if the single room was at the same discounted rate as listed on the web site the previous evening. He put me on hold and contacted the hotel again and discussed this with the office manager. She spoke loudly and sounded very agitated. After their call, my call with the CHCS clerk was cut off. The office manager said it didn't matter, since the CHCS clerk would just tell me that there was only one double room available and the other room would be only $14 less.Again, I said this was unacceptable and asked her to reconnect me to CHCS. She then told me that they had two double rooms available. She said that we would need to pay $12 extra per person though. We said that we would not pay any extra charges than those on the printed copy of our reservation. She did not seem happy this response, but proceeded to check us in. She said something like "I thought you would have been more understanding, but I guess you don't want to work with me". I thought it was very unprofessional for an office manager to behave this way while other customers were in the lobby, overhearing this entire fiasco.Because our check-in process was so disastrous (about 20 minutes), none of us enjoyed our stay at the hotel. We would definitely warn others not to stay at this hotel, based on our experience, plus other reviews we've read since then. Make sure to check out other reviews with low ratings. Several of them describe very similar stories. There are several other nice hotels in the same area and price range, so make sure to choose your hotel wisely.When we filed a formal complaint with CHCS, we were told that someone in upper management of the hotel would contact us within 7 days. It has been 2 weeks now and we still haven't received a call from anyone at the hotel.

Stayed in the comfort inn midtown, with my boyfriend. Being students we didn't have a great deal to spend on a hotel so we thought that the Comfort Inn sounded reasonable. I wasn't sure what to expect, but as we entered our room we were really pleased with what we saw. The room was sparkling and was cleaned everyday. The staff were really friendly and couldn't do enough to help. The situation of the hotel couldn't be better. Just a stones throw from Times Square, Empire State Building, Macy's and 5th Avenue all within short walking distance. Once we left I realised I had left my wash bag at the hotel, full of brand new and unused Clinique products and MAC makeup, which I never thought I would see again. The next day my cousin went to the hotel on my behalf to enquire about my bag, to our surprise had been handed in by the maid, containing the full contents. This alone is a reason to stay at the Comfort Inn Midtown. It really put the icing on the cake for my boyfriend and I and made our trip to the city a happy memory.

OK, I just returned from NYC and the very first thing I am doing is to let everyone know that the previous reviews were right on the mark. We spent three nights here and the place was far and away the best value you will find within miles of Times Square. We (me, wife, 19 y.o., 17 y.o.) stayed in one of their eight double-double rooms. The room was clean, comfortable and quiet, if you don't count the occasional bells of the beautiful church next door! The bathroom was much bigger than expected and the towels were great, despite some previous postings to the contrary. The staff was nothing short of fabulous, especially Dioris and Jovanni behind the counter, and Sidibi and Kenneth, the bellmen. We got there far too early to be checked in, so they took our luggage and stored it securely for us, while we went out and explored. They even pointed out that a festival was going on down on 6th Avenue (away from Times Square) and we should check it out. I know big hotels will do things such as this, but a budget hotel on Times Square? They also knew lots of little secrets and are more than willing to share with you, if you ask.The hallways are incredibly narrow, but also very well-lit. You never once felt as though the place was old and dingy. The elevator was indeed slower than it should be, but with only 80 rooms, we never waited more than a minute or two, and that was rarely. Be careful, though. The elevator door closes so fast that it can smack into you pretty hard if you are not paying attention. Make sure you are holding it with your hand or that someone has the button pushed for you. They have free continental breakfast, which was simply muffins, donuts, cereal, and fruit. But seriously, how much more do you need in NYC? You don't go there to have great breakfasts. We ate quickly and then went out and did what we wanted. The only thing that I will ask them to change when I send in my review to them is to adjust the pressure on the door closers in each room. If you are trying to sleep and the neighbors are not considerate when entering/exiting their room, the door slams shut loudly. The good news is that each hall is divided in half by the elevator shaft, so you really only have about six rooms in your half of the hallway to be disturbed by. They have a computer with internet access in the business center so that those of us who don't want to haul around one on vacation can still check email and weather reports, etc. You can even print out (for free) maps of todays destinations, subways, whatever. Parking was a relative bargain at $20 per day. It is just across the street, about 1/4 block away.I'll sum up by saying this: I will stay in this hotel again the next time I am in NYC. I will not look for a better deal because there is not one to be had.

Although the front desk female attendant in the evening was talking on the phone with her friend while checking me into a room, the rest of the staff were very friendly particular the bell men. They were very helpful. In addition the maid and housekeeping were also attentive. The value of the room was also impressive. Marble bathroom floors, decorative furniture, right price, excellent locationa and a friendly staff...what else could you ask for.I will come back again to stay in this fine Hotel.A+++++++++

My stay was for 2 nights--17th/18th March 2005.My room was clean with two single beds--booking was only for one person. Check in was quick, and a room was ready--even at 11 AM.The location is GREAT--so close to everywhere.The "homely" little breakfast room--just off the lobby--was nice, with plenty of everything, to start your day off well.If, this Australian traveller--ever gets back to New York City, again. I would NOT hesitate to book at the Comfort Inn, again. D.T. Brisbane Australia

We had a very pleasant stay here. I chose this hotel based on the reviews on this site and write-ups in a couple of travel books. Everyone's comments proved to be very accurate. The hotel is 1/2 block east of Times Square directly across the street from the very hip looking Muse Hotel. The street is quiet and we did not have any problems with security. In short, the location can't be beat. Great access to several subway stations gets you wherever you want to go in minutes, theater district is just a few blocks away, Radio City right around the corner, MOMA a couple of blocks past that. Many restaurants are within walking distance. You could walk to Grand Central if you weren't lugging bags. The hotel is very clean, the staff quite pleasant. The wi-fi worked perfectly. Breakfast is included, served in a small room off the lobby, and it is simple (bagels, doughnuts, dry cereals, fruit), but plenty to get you on your way in the morning. This is a small homey-type hotel, the photos on the web site make it look larger than it is. There is a small sitting area and window seat in the lobby, the front desk, a small exercise room, computer room and meeting room. The lobby is very clean and nicely renovated. I believe there are only 8 guest floors, with maybe 12 or so rooms on each floor. There is only one elevator, but we did not experience the excessively long waits that other reviewers have described. Our room was on the 5th floor, and it was an easy walk to take the stairs instead if we wanted. The room itself was quite small, maybe 10x12 feet? with a Queen bed, nightstand, small desk, small armoire with TV. The view out the window was of the brick wall of the next building, it would probably be nicer to choose one of the front rooms if you can. Each room has a window-mounted A/C unit - and this was our biggest complaint, it was very loud when on hi speed, somewhat less noisy when on its lowest setting. The bathroom was relatively large considering the bedroom size, and very nice, tiled all around with a pedestal sink, toilet, tub/shower. The towels are rather thin. Soap and shampoo/conditioner combo are provided, other than that, you'll need to bring your own toiletries.At the end of our stay, we checked out in the morning and checked our bags with the doorman until we were ready to leave later in the afternoon. When we returned to collect the bags, one of the people at the front desk called to me and told me I had left something in my room. I was very pleasantly surprised that she knew me by sight and room number as she handed my camera charger to me.I am normally a more luxury-oriented traveler, so I was concerned about choosing a "value" hotel. If you're the same way, but are willing to forego some of the amenities, this is a great choice. When it came right down to it, we didn't spend much time in the room anyway. The breakfast was a nice bonus, the location was fantastic and you can't beat the price -- we were able to happily spend our money instead on fun things like show tickets, etc. -- all in all, it worked great for us. P.S. If you are a AAA member, show your card when you check in. We were given $10 additional off the rate I had already booked with a AAA discount.

Booked this hotel for 7 nights in June based on tripadvisor and couldn't be more pleased that we did. We were a little concerned that an inexpensive Manhattan hotel ($143 plus tax) might not be clean or well maintained but our concerns were swept away. The bathroom was spacious and modernized with a great shower/tub with good pressure, tile floors, upgraded faucets, hair dryer, and cleaned immaculately every day with fresh towels, soap, etc. The queen bed was comfortable, sheets changed daily, had a large TV but no time to watch, and an effective air conditioner. Large walkin closet and ample drawers. Small quibble-only one side of bed had a reading lamp. Window looked out onto a wall which was OK because who goes to NY to look out hotel window? Advantage as it also meant very quiet. I am a light sleeper but had no trouble having full night's sleep every night. Included breakfast featured bagels, donuts, two cereals, fresh fruit, yogurt, two juices, toast, coffee, tea and even machine brewed espresso. This saved time and money finding a breakfast restaurant in expensive NYC. I thought I would use the small exercise room (treadmills, exercise bicycle), but because of the central location, we walked most places and didn't need the extra exercise. Highly recommended for budget travellers!

For the price, this was a super hotel. Not quite excellent, but I didn't expect excellent for ~240 (incl. tax) per night in NYC.Room was clean, bathroom was good-sized for NYC with a good shower. The hotel was quiet, surprising for midtown, and the service was pleasant. Absolutely no view and not much room to walk around in the room itself, but those are very minor quibbles.Location can't be beat. I booked the hotel on the recommendations of other posts here, and I wasn't disappointed. In fact, we're going to stay there again in August.

Booked this hotel for a week in June after reading other reviews on this site. It was exactly as we expected, and we were very satisfied. Not the Ritz, but who wants to pay for that when you're out sightseeing all day anyway? Would stay there again.Pros:-Perfect Location (close to: Times Sq., theatre dist, Rockefeller Ctr, metro stops)-Comfortable rooms (small, but adequate)-Very clean -Great customer service-Free continental breakfast was very good-Did I mention the location?Cons: (If you can call them that, they were *not* a big deal)-No onsite bar or restaurant (Lounge at hotel across the street is cool)-Slow elevator (So, take the stairs)-A/C a bit loud (At least there is air conditioning!)-No view (Only in the room at night to sleep anyway)

I can easily rate the Comfort Inn as excellent on all fronts, however I know there is another level of Hotels in NYC, so I will stop at 4 stars. If the prices are in your budget, stay there.Service was great, the people were really nice. We arrived at 11:00 and got the room straight away, which was small, but very comfortable with a great bathroom (room 600). They helped with directions and some bandaids when we needed them. When we left they let us stay until 13:15 as our flights were not 'till 15:00. Works for me.You will be 1 block from Time Square and right in the middle of Manhatten so if you want to get uptown or downtown, you are half way there. If you need a good cheap lunch, turn left out of the hotel and it is five or six down on the right.

What a find! In researching a hotel for a group attending a conference in Times Square, it was my mission to get the "best bang for the buck". I went directly to tripadvisor & locked into the Comfort Inn Midtown immediately. The location is excellent (1/2 block out of Times Square), the rooms are small...but spotless. The bedding was great, the bathroom was clean and well kept, and the noise (except for the air conditioner) was minimal. Breakfast room was clean, well stocked and had a nice variety of goodies. Listen, for $150/night in NYC - this hotel is a gem!!!!

This hotel is steps away from all the action of Time Square. To my convience this hotel is two blocks from the Belasco Theater. I paid about $179.00 a night, which is a wonderful deal for Midtown. The hotel rooms are very clean. The rooms are also very small; the rooms are big enough to fit a queen size bed, a nice size entertainment system, and a table with chair. Each room has a private bathroom with shower and tub. The room also had a head dryer, coffe maker, air, iron and ironing board; which is great for those that like to pack lite. There's nine floors to this hotel with only one elevator. I didn't fid this to be a problem at all, because the hotel is pretty small.

Stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown for the first time. I was a bit reluctant to book this hotel because of the awfully low price of $159, however was pleasantly surprised at the great location, hospitality and cleanliness the hotel has to offer. I would not recommend this hotel for families as the rooms are a bit small. Overall was a good experience and definitely would stay there again.

Myself and 25year old son stayed at the comfort Inn on Jan 2005 for six nights. This hotel was excellent its in a great location just a short walk on to Times Square and handy for site seeing in New York. I asked for a queit room which l got no view looking onto a gable wall but l didnt care as long as you got a nights sleep and it was a queit room. Very clean and towels changed every day. Breakfast was a bonus too which was a good start to the day. Reasonablly priced for New York hotels. Would stay again at this hotel.

I stayed at the Comfort Inn Midtown for 5 days in June. I booked this hotel based on the reviews on this site and I'm happy that I did. This hotel is the best kept secret in Manhattan. The location is perfect as it's on a side street away from the hustle & bustle of Times Square but close enough and within walking distance to everything. If you're traveling alone or with a partner this is a great hotel to stay. However, if you're traveling with children or large groups I would recommend staying at a hotel with much bigger rooms as the rooms are small here and they do not offer rollaways. The front desk staff were courteous and friendly and the bellman was terrific. Although there is only one elevator I never had to wait long. My room had a queen size bed and bath/shower so I must have lucked out and got one of the bigger rooms. The room was always neat and tidy. Although breakfast is offered between 7-10 if you miss it there are plenty of eateries close to the hotel. If you're arriving from JFK I would recommend taking one of the shuttles to the hotel this way you can see a little of NY and will only cost $17 instead of the $45 for a taxicab ride. Also, when I left for the airport I used the car service that the hotel provides. For about the same amount of money to take a cab I opted for the ride to JFK in a nice A/C luxury vehicle and it was worth every cent. Just ask the bellman or the front desk and they will set it up for you. I have to say my stay at the Comfort Inn Midtown was the best and I would highly recommend this to family and friends. I will definitely stay at this hotel again.

Read reviews here before choosing Comfort Inn Midtown, and I am glad I did! We had a wonderful stay! The location and price cannot be beat! It is right across from the Muse Hotel, which I understand is pricier!Room we had was nice, clean and quiet. Room was smaller and narrower than what I'm accustomed to...so were the hallways and stairway, but I was mentally prepared for that.All the staff were very friendly....who said New Yorkers were rude?You are right on W46th which is called Little Brazil...and on the other side of Broadway, it's Restaurant Row! W 47th is Diamond Row, and all the theaters are all within nice walking distance. You can also walk to 5th Avenue from here and shop till you drop, and have access to other major tourist attractions (Grand Central station, Rockefeller center, etc.) You are also next to a church...and those church bells in the morning are actually quite comforting!Check out the little Cuban restaurant across the street! Oh, and there's a manicure/pedicure place a couple of doors down for a quick makeover before a show.Don't expect wide open spaces, swimming pools, etc. This is a nice place to come home to after a full day of exploring NYC.

This was my first stay at the Comfort Inn (June 4-11) and I was very pleased. The hotel is clean, staff members are friendly and helpful, free high-speed internet is provided in the lobby, and the continental breakfast was excellent and food plentiful. In addition, the hotel is conveniently located about 1/2 block from Times Square. The room was rather small and plain, but very clean and well-maintained. I have stayed in "budget" hotels before in New York, and this one has been, by far, the best. For $139/night, I cannot think of a better bargain for your dollar. I will definitely stay at this hotel again the next time I am in New York.

We stayed there for 4 nights and found it a very good hotel. Small but clean rooms, not a great view but very quiet. Elevator is slow, we took the stairs sometimes. The price was reasonable for NYC and the breakfast was free. Very close to Time Square and other attractions. We would definitely stay there again.

After spending weeks on this site searching for good hotels for my first visit to NYC, I chose the Comfort Inn Midtown. I stayed here on 5/31 through 6/2. Yeah it's small, but it's quaint and cozy with Times Square just footsteps away. The room was very clean with no blemishes on the towels, carpeting or room/bathroom fixtures. I had a great time here and will definitely stay here again for my next trip to NYC.

When travelling on a budget, particularly to somewhere like Manhattan, it is very easy to find most of your precious dollars swallowed up by accommodation. By staying at the Comfort Inn, my wife and I had more money in our pocket to go out and enjoy the city - which after all, is what it is all about! Our 7-night stay at the Comfort Inn Midtown in May, while having no outstanding features, was comfortable and trouble-free; in other words, it did the job we wanted of it, and it did it admirably!Our expectations of the hotel - and our reasons for choosing it - were based on the reviews here. I guess we expected something a little run-down (but not too much), somewhat noisy at the front, perhaps occasional problems with the cleanliness of the bathrooms or linen. A few reviews suggested that some people found staff to be a little unfriendly or brusque, and that the breakfast provided "ran out" if you weren't there early enough. So we figured that at worst the hotel may be a little unpleasant, but for $130 a night we could live with that.It was a pleasant surprise then, when even our minor apprehensions were proven to be dead wrong. The room was clean and seemed quite new.
